myths.name: Hy Brasil
myths.pseudonym: O'Brasil, Bracile; Brazyl; Brasil Rock; Insula de Monotonis; Insula de Brazile
myths.title3: Composite: Tavola 1-4. (Map of the World) (Urbano Monte, 1587)
myths.title2: El mar Mediterráneo (Cresques Abraham, 1375)
myths.title: Europae (Abraham Ortelius, 1571)
myths.description:
Unrelated to its South American namesake, this legendary isle's name is thought to originate from the Uí Breasail (meaning 'descendants of Bresail'), one of the ancient clans of northeastern Ireland. Celtic folklore describes Hy Brasil as a place rarely seen, being permanently cloaked in mist except for one day every seven years. Ruled by King Breasal, the High King of the World, Hy Brasil was also said to be a wondrous paradise, offering eternal happiness and immortality.

Rumours of its existence were stoked further in 1675 by the publication of a satirical pamphlet by Richard Head that recounted the travels of the fictional Captain John Nisbet. Nisbet and his crew had stumbled upon the island en route to County Donegal from France, finding only an abandoned and half-demolished castle. That night, after the sailors had lit a fire, a 'very ancient grave Gentleman' who spoke 'the old Scotch Language' appeared, explaining that their presence had lifted a centuries-old spell that had rendered the island invisible. Nisbet was richly rewarded by the islanders and returned to Killybegs with many gifts of gold and silver.

Since its appearances on early 14th century maps, this rich and enduring mythology helped it to survive on maps for a further 500 years and well into the 19th century, latterly being downgraded to the more diminutive Brasil Rock.

myths.name: Antillia
myths.pseudonym: Isle of Seven Cities; Sept Citez; Roillo; Ymana
myths.title: The portolan chart (Albino de Canepa, 1489)
myths.title2: Americae Sive Novi Orbis, Nova Descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.description:
The island of Antillia originates from an old Iberian legend set during the Muslim conquest of Hispania c. 714. Seeking to flee from their Muslim conquerors, seven Christian bishops escaped with their parishioners and set sail westwards, eventually landing on an island where they founded seven settlements within the island's bays.

By the 1490s there were rumours amongst Spanish and Portuguese sailors that silver and gold could be found in the island's sands. Columbus too considered it as a potential resting point en route to the Indies.

Depictions of Antillia and its companion, Royllo/Ymana, gradually disappeared during the 16th century as shipping traffic began to increase across the Atlantic, though it nonetheless lent its name to the Spanish Antilles.

myths.name: Satanazes
myths.pseudonym: Isle of Devils; Hand of Satan; Ya de la man santanaxio; Tanmar; Danmar
myths.title: Portolan chart (Zuane Pizzigano, 1424)
myths.description:
Unlike its southern counterpart, Antillia, there is little agreement on how Satanazes and its umbrella-shaped neighbour, Saya, became a phantom island. On 15th century maps it is typically drawn as a large rectangular island, indented with bays and five or six settlements.

Loosely translated to 'Isle of Devils', historians have conjectured these 'devils' might be a reference to the Skrælings (indigenous peoples of Greenland and Vinland) reported in the Norse sagas that began to filter south around the 15th century.

Others have even conjectured that given its latitude, Satanazes may represent an early depiction of North America, and more specifically, Nova Scotia. In some maps, the island is labelled 'Ya de la man santanaxio', translated to 'Isle of the Hand of Satan'. In 1783 Vicenzo Formaleoni linked this name to the sea-faring legend of a giant hand that would drag sailors and boats to the bottom of the ocean. Satanazes disappeared from maps after the voyages of Christopher Columbus in the 1490s, with its legendary origin still unresolved today.

myths.name: Rupes Nigra
myths.title: Septentrionalium Terrarum Descriptio (Gerardus Mercator, 1628)
myths.description:
Why do compasses point north? According to the ancient Greek geographer, Ptolemy, a large magnetic rock at the pole was the answer. This notion remained through to the 16th century; in a letter to John Dee in 1577, Gerardus Mercator further described the Arctic island as:

'In the midst of the four countries is a Whirl-pool, into which there empty these four indrawing Seas which divide the North. And the water rushes round and descends into the Earth just as if one were pouring it through a filter funnel. It is four degrees wide on every side of the Pole, that is to say eight degrees altogether. Except that right under the Pole there lies a bare Rock in the midst of the Sea. Its circumference is almost 33 French miles, and it is all of magnetic Stone.'

The source of his information came from a now-lost travelogue from the 14th century, Inventio Fortunata, describing the wanderings of a Franciscan friar who explored the North Atlantic on behalf of King Edward III of England.

By the time Mercator published his famous map of the Arctic in 1595, he appears to have embraced ideas of magnetic deviation by proposing two new rocks north of the Strait of Anian as the magnetic pole.

myths.name: Polus Arcticus
myths.title: Tavola 1-4 (Map of the World - composite) (Urbano Monte, 1587)
myths.title2: Septentrionalium Terrarum Descriptio (Gerard Mercator, 1628)
myths.description:
The unexplored North Pole was a region of total mystery for early mapmakers. At the end of the 15th century, the first depictions of vast lands across the Arctic appeared on maps, which were predominantly based off the travels of a Franciscan friar in 1360. Writing on his 1507 map, Ruysch cited his source:

'In the book De Inventione Fortunata it may be read that at the North Pole there is a high mountain of magnetic stone 33 German miles in circumference. This is surrounded by mare sugunum which pours out water like a vessel through openings below. Around it are four islands, surrounded by extensive desolate mountains for 24 days’ journey, where there is no human habitation.'

In Mercator's 1595 map of the Arctic, he even describes that one of the islands is home to 4-feet tall pygmies. As new discoveries in the High Arctic emerged, such as that of Spitsbergen in 1596, these lands had to be modified, and in later versions of Mercator's map the land of pygmies became much reduced. Over the next few decades, these rumoured conceptions of the Arctic, including the four countries, a large maelstrom, and a magnetic Rupes Nigra, would vanish altogether from maps.

myths.name: Saint Brendan's Island
myths.pseudonym: Aprositus; Black Rock; St Brandain Island; San Borondon; Promised Land of the Saints
myths.title: Hereford Mappa Mundi - Fortunate Insulae sex sunt Insulae Sct Brandani (1300)
myths.title2: Nova Typis Transacta Navigatio (Caspar Plautius, 1621)
myths.description:
The Voyage of St Brendan and the island he discovered is a famous sea tale from Irish history that recounts a fantastic 7-year search for the 'Promised Land of the Saints' in AD 512. Written records of the voyage did not appear for another 300 years, so the details surrounding Brendan's odyssey are highly inconsistent. Nevertheless, St Brendan of Clonfert and his band of 14 monks wandered widely in search of the warm island and had many adventures.

According to legend, these included stumbling upon giant sea creatures, landing on an island that was actually a whale, discovering an island with sheep as large as oxen, and another with talking birds. They also came upon Judas Iscariot sitting on a rock in the middle of the sea, apparently on his annual respite from the torments of hell.

After 43 days at sea (records vary on this point), and with rations almost depleted, their ship finally reached the earthly paradise they were seeking, filled with beautiful fruits and abundant flowers, and where neither nocturnal darkness nor winter cold were known. For seven years the monks happily remained here, and made numerous visits to other nearby islands before returning home to their monastery in Clonfert.

St Brendan's destination was initially associated with the Canaries, particularly by the Spanish and Portuguese, though was later shifted by mapmakers once the attentions of explorers migrated north and westwards.

myths.name: Sea of the West
myths.pseudonym: Mer de l'Ouest; Baye de l'Ouest; Sea of Verrazano; Archipel du Nord
myths.title: L'Amerique Septentrionale Divisee en ses Principaux Etats (Janvier, 1762)
myths.title2: Novae Insulae XVII Nova Tabula (Sebastian Munster, 1540)
myths.description:
Notions of a large sea dissecting North America stem back to the 1524 expedition by Giovanni da Verrazano that explored the region around Newfoundland. Beyond the Outer Banks of North Carolina Verrazano was able to see Pamlico Sound, the largest lagoon along the eastern coast of the US. He mistook the lagoon as being the Pacific Ocean and thus began the myth of the Sea of Verrazano.

By the 18th century, depictions of a large inland sea had reemerged based on separate (and dubious) accounts of exploration by Juan de Fuca and the fictional Bartholomew de Fonte. De Fuca had apparently journeyed up a vast strait at the northernmost point of America's west coast, around which he enjoyed 'sailing therein more than twenty days'.

In 1703, Guillaume de L'Isle became the first to map these rumours more definitively, and by 1750 Philippe Buache had drawn 'La Mer de l'Ouest' to dominate the largely unexplored portions of northwest Canada. The tenacity of cartographers to keep depicting this 'Sea of the West' on more than 200 maps during the 18th century was no doubt compounded by economic interests in Europe for discovering a navigable trading route through North America. Subsequent charting of the Pacific Northwest coastline by James Cook, Vitus Bering and others dwindled prospects of finding a great sea by the end of the century.

myths.name: River of the West
myths.pseudonym: R. de l'Ouest; Fleuve de L'Ouest; River Aguilar; River Thegaya
myths.title: Carte D'Amerique (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1722)
myths.title2: Nouveau Mexique, Louisiane, Canada, et les Etats Unis (Louis Brion de La Tour, 1786)
myths.description:
During an expedition led by Sebastián Vizcaíno in 1602 in search of usable harbours along the west coast of North America, Martín de Aguilar located a major river mouth around the 45th parallel. Initially it was thought to be the Strait of Anian, but in actuality it was probably the Colombia River.

Guillaume de L'Isle later depicted this entrance on his 1722 map of the Americas, alongside a relatively modest river further inland labelled, 'Grande Riviere coulant a l'ouest' - an observation likely derived from accounts provided by Native Americans to the French.

By 1743, this river had grown in stature, extending from the west coast through to Lake Winnipeg, thus providing a possible route all the way to Hudson Bay. By the end of the 18th century, however, explorations of the North American continent by sea and by land had dampened any notion of such a great river or a more temperate route for the long sought-after Northwest Passage.

myths.name: Caspian Sea
myths.title: Tabula Asiae VII (Sebastian Munster, 1540)
myths.title2: Nova Et Accvratissima Totius Terrarvm Orbis Tabvla (Joan Blaeu, 1665)
myths.description:
The Caspian Sea has been a permanent fixture on historical maps. But its depiction by western cartographers took a radical change around the early 16th century when its orientation switched from its actual north-south orientation to east-west.

This reimagining of the world's largest lake likely stemmed from the influence of newly available translations of much older works of the Greek geographer, Ptolemy, undoing the work of Arabs who had already successfully charted the Caspian during the centuries before. The correct orientation would not appear again consistently on Western maps until the 18th century.

myths.name: Lac de Fonte
myths.pseudonym: Lac Belle; Lac de Valasco; Lac de Ronquillo
myths.title: Carte des nouvelles découvertes au nord de la Mer du Sud : tant à l'est de la Siberie et du Kamtchatka, qu'à l'ouest de la Nouvelle France (Philippe Buache and Guillaume de L'Isle, 1752)
myths.title2: Nuove Scoperte de' Russi al nord del Mare del Sud si nell' Asia (Antonio Zatta, 1776)
myths.description:
The series of lakes and rivers traversing across most of North America towards the Baffin and Hudson bays are based on the mythical voyages of the Spanish admiral Bartholomew de Fonte, which first appeared in a 1708 English publication Monthly Miscellany.

During de Fonte's supposed voyage up the Pacific coastline in 1640 he discovered a series of gigantic inland lakes and waterways. In the Strait of Ronquillo he met with a westward-bound ship from Boston commanded by Captain Shapely, suggesting a Northwest Passage was feasible. A second group under the command of Captain Bernardo traveled up the River de Haro and went on to discover Lake Valasco.

Despite a lack of supporting Spanish material to substantiate even the existence of Admiral de Fonte, the desire that such a passage could exist through the North American continent helped fuel this myth, and even received support from figures such as Benjamin Franklin.

myths.name: Mayda
myths.pseudonym: Maida; Mayd; Brazir; Mam; Man; Bentusla; Asmaidas; As Maydas; Onzele; Isola de Maydi; Demar
myths.title: Tablua Terre Nove (Martin Waldseemüller, 1513)
myths.title2: Europae (Abraham Ortelius, 1571)
myths.description:
Mayda, with its many pseudonyms, is one of the most enduring phantom islands of the North Atlantic, though its origin is largely unknown; despite its popularity with cartographers for over five centuries, no recorded accounts exist of anyone having visited its shores.

Its signature crescent shape first appears in 1367 with the label Brazir, though its common name of Mayda appeared only later in 1553. Other maps provide the name Demar for the island. It has been speculated Mayda could have been a very early depiction of Corvo in the Azores, or even the crescent shaped lands of Bermuda, Cape Cod or Cape Breton in the Americas.

Was it really a mythological land though? In 1948 a 45 km-wide point of land at coordinates of 46°23′N 37°20′W was discovered submerged only 36.5 m below the ocean surface. Significantly, this location due west of Brittany tallies with the earliest map drawings.

myths.name: Sandy Island
myths.title2: Australian, N.Z. ports. (George Philip, 1922)
myths.title: Pacific Ocean in four sheets : comprised between the parallels of 37 degrees North and 37 degrees South and extending from the Philippine and Celebes Is., New Guinea and Australia, to San Francisco and Easter Island. (R.C. Carrington, 1875)
myths.description:
Sandy Island is a phantom that slipped through onto charts and digital maps well into the 21st century. Its origins begin with Captain James Cook in 1774 who first recorded a Sandy Island in this region as part of the real Grand Terre reef encasing New Caledonia.

Over a century later in 1876, the whaling ship Velocity also sighted 'Sandy Island', this time ~480 km farther east than Cook's position, with the location later marked on British Admiralty charts.

While the French Hydrographic Service had removed the island from its nautical charts in 1974, Australian scientists on board RV Southern Surveyor undiscovered the island again in November 2012, finding the ocean floor at its supposed location never became 'shallower than 1300 metres below the wave base'. Its removal from Google Maps followed a few days later.

Given its location on a pumice 'superhighway' some believe the sightings by the Velocity were of giant pumice rafts. However, its entrenchment in 21st century digital maps, such as those used by scientists and Google, likely traces back to when hard-copy charts were converted to digital formats.

myths.name: Lake Cassipa
myths.title: Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana (Nicolas Sanson, 1679)
myths.title2: Nieuwe caerte van het Wonderbaer ende Goudrjcke Landt Guiana (Jodocus Hondius, 1598)
myths.description:
The imaginary Lake Cassipa is tied to the mythology of El Dorado and the search for vast riches of gold in South America by Sir Walter Raleigh. He noted that when this lake receded, large deposits of gold would be revealed. Yet what Raleigh described as a lake was most likely misconstrued as a tributary to the lower Orinoco River.

In this region where the land is extremely flat, floods can easily mask the true nature of the river bed. For example, the Paragua/Parava River here translates to 'sea' or 'great lake' in the local Caribbee language. The name, Cassipa, given by Raleigh, derives from the Cassipagotos ('great tribe') who lived here. Lake Cassipa persisted on maps for most of the 18th century, though latterly in a much reduced form.

myths.name: Lake Parime
myths.pseudonym: Lake Parima; Mer de Parime; El Dorado; Manoa; White Sea; Mar Blanco
myths.title: Guaiana (Hessel Gerritsz, 1625)
myths.title2: Nieuwe caerte van het Wonderbaer ende Goudrjcke Landt Guiana (Jodocus Hondius, 1598)
myths.description:
Columbus' arrival in Latin America in 1492 marked the beginning of a lucrative gold rush for the Spanish, and by 1560 they had shipped 101 tons home from the New World. A legend arose of a fabulously rich king, El Dorado (The Gilded One) within the jungle heartland, who would ritually wash in Lake Guatavita to remove ornamental powdered gold from his body. The idea of El Dorado morphed from being a single man to a city, and even a kingdom.

Many searches ensued, and while the Spanish eventually became convinced of El Dorado's non-existence, Sir Walter Raleigh's arrival in Guyana in 1594 renewed enthusiasm for its search.

Raleigh conflated El Dorado with another lost city, Manoa, which he located on the legendary Lake Parime far up the Orinoco River in Venezuela. According to him, the lake itself was the source of the gold possessed by the people of Manoa. Explorers have since proposed that the seasonal flooding of the Rupununi savannah may have led to the misidentification of a lake.

myths.name: Senkaku Islands
myths.title: Apple Maps, 2012
myths.description:
The digital age is not immune to cartographic blunders. In 2012 the newly released Apple Maps inadvertently provided a diplomatic solution to China and Japan's ongoing dispute over the Senkaku Islands by charting a duplicate archipelago to the northeast - one for each country. This error can still be found in Google Earth with its sea-surface masking algorithm accounting for this second archipelago, even though the islands do not appear on satellite imagery.

The source of the error probably stems from a combination of the inclusion of Chinese raw data and the 'China GPS shift problem' - a class of issues that cause displacement between the Chinese GCJ-02 datum and the WGS-84 datum used by the Global Positioning System. A design feature of the GCJ-02 datum is an obfuscation algorithm that randomly offsets coordinates, often by over 500 metres.

myths.name: Bermeja
myths.title: Portolano (Gaspar Luis Vegas, 1535)
myths.title2: Nova Hispania, Nova Galicia, Guatimala (John Ogilby, 1671)
myths.description:
When negotiations began in 1998 between the US and Mexico on how to delimit their exclusive economic zones in the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico's hopes for a more expansive territory lay on a small island - Bermeja - found on many historic charts going back to the 16th century.

With no physical evidence forthcoming for the island, the Clinton-Zedillo accords of 09 June 2000 were signed, and the borders were fixed. However, with an agreement to only begin oil drilling projects in 2011, there was still time to potentially find Bermeja and reverse the treaty. In 2009, three separately funded expeditions set out from Mexico to scour its supposed location, but each came back empty-handed. Had the island simply vanished?

Bermeja first appears on a portolan chart made by Gaspar Luis Viegas around 1535. Its coordinates at 23°N were later catalogued in 1537 by Alonso de Santa Cruz, who also described the island as looking reddish from a distance. A few years later he would also include Bermeja in his 1539 atlas, Islario general de todas las islas del mundo.

Bermeja would persist on maps over the coming centuries despite no further sightings. The last Mexican government-printed schoolbook showing Isla Bermeja was released in 1946.

Explanations for its disappearance have ranged from rising sea levels to destruction by an earthquake. Yet a more radical suggestion was proposed by some Mexican lawmakers, notably José Ángel Conchello Dávila, who claimed it had been destroyed by the Central Intelligence Agency to nullify Mexican claims in the gulf. It is more probable that 16th-century reports had confused Bermeja with the Cayo Arenas reef nearby to the south.

myths.name: Negrillo
myths.title: Nova Hispania, Nova Galicia, Guatimala (John Ogilby, 1671)
myths.title2: Carte Generale des Iles Antilles (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1845)
myths.description:
Within the neighbourhood of the elusive island of Bermeja can be found another phantom shoal, Negrillo. Known to early Spanish explorers in the early 16th century, one encounter described Negrillo as a tiny rock around half a boat's length in extent and no more than 6 metres below the sea.

A 1775 expedition led by Aldereté and Valderrama, and with the prime purpose of locating this shoal according the the old charts, failed to find it.

It was supposedly located in 1806 by Captain Don Domingo Casalo of the schooner Villavonesa at coordinates 23° 25'N, 90° 12' 37"W. According to the captain the shoal was no more than one quarter of a cable in extent (46 m), over which the water washed, except at its two extremities.

Despite these numerous descriptions, Negrillo would disappear from maps altogether by the end of the 19th century.

myths.name: Bozo's Rock
myths.title: Topographical Map of America (James T. Lloyd, 1871)
myths.description:
This shoal was reported on 8th December, 1817, by the pilot Don Manuel Bozo of the Spanish bombard Nuestra Senora del Carmen. He estimated the danger to be about 500 m in length, and at both ends saw two rocks or pinnacles about 1 metre high. Weather conditions at the time were calm, but still the heavy breakers over it could not be mistaken.

Having sighted the rock after only 3 day's sailing from port the given position was accepted as reasonably correct. However, it would not go on to appear on many maps from the 19th century, and reference to it eventually disappeared altogether in the early 20th century.

myths.name: Buss Island
myths.title: Nieuwe Wassende Kaart van een gedeelte der Noorder Atlantische Oceaan (G Hulst van Keulen, 1786)
myths.title2: Luke Foxe's map of his 1631 exploration of Hudson Bay
myths.description:
Buss Island was 'discovered' during Martin Frobisher's return from his third and final expedition in search of a Northwest Passage. It was named after the type of vessel used by its discoverers.

Further sightings in 1668 and 1671, reporting that 'the island affords store of Whales, easie to be struck' helped keep the myth alive. Later, in 1675, the Hudson's Bay Company paid £65 (worth £11,000 today) for exclusive economic rights and ownership of the island in perpetuity to King Charles II, despite no-one having ever set foot there.

The island's supposed size reduced as Atlantic traffic increased, and by 1745 was renamed the Sunken Land of Buss by the Dutch cartographer, Van Keulen.

myths.name: Fata Morgana Land
myths.title: A fata morgana
myths.description: Numerous sightings of land in this vicinity were made between 1907 and 1937, including from the air. It was later named Fata Morgana Land, after a type of mirage common in polar regions, with the non-existent island likely a distortion of Tobias Island - a barren rocky island 70 km from NE Greenland whose position was determined with accuracy only in 1993.

myths.name: Dougherty Island
myths.title: Süd-Polar-Meer (Justus Perthes, 1906)
myths.title2: The Antarctic Regions (Edward Stanford, c.1914)
myths.description:
Captain Dougherty, an English whaler, discovered this 6-mile wide island in 1841, the credence for which was supported by a report from 1800 of Swain Island spotted in the same general vicinity. Numerous captains would spot the island over subsequent decades, establishing its inclusion on charts of the area. For example, in 1859 and at the same latitude and a degree farther east, Captain Keates also found a round island with a large iceberg run aground on the northwest side.

In 1909, Chief Officer Davis of Ernest Shackleton's 1908–1909 Antarctic expedition suggested they had all been deceived by fog banks or icebergs: 'I am inclined to think Dougherty Island has melted.' Further disproof of this island came in 1931 by Captain Mackenzie of the exploratory vessel Discovery, who measured a depth of 2470 fathoms at its supposed location.

myths.name: Swain Island
myths.description:
Captain Abraham Swain of the whaler Charles reported an island here in 1800. Twenty-five years later, Captain Macy also reported land at roughly the same latitude, but 1 degree further west at 91°W. This became know as Macy/Macy's Island.

The brig Annawan and schooner Penguin, which had left Staten Island in 1830, made a search for these two islands in the hope of securing seal skins though found nothing.

Their last appearance can be found in a 1974 Soviet Atlas of the Pacific Ocean.

myths.name: Emerald Island
myths.title: Oceania, or Islands in the Pacific Ocean (A. Fullarton & Co, 1872)
myths.title2: Süd-Polar-Karte (1912, A. Petermann)
myths.description:
The 'semblance' of this island, thirty miles long with high peaked mountains, was sighted by C.J. Nockells of the British sealing ship Emerald, in 1821. Lt Wilkes of the US Exploring Expedition of 1838-42 later attempted to use Emerald Island as a rendezvous point for his fleet during its approach to Antarctica, without success.

A further search for the island in 1909 by Shackleton's Nimrod also turned up nothing, suggesting the island was likely a mistaken iceberg. The abyssal plain on the ocean floor beneath the location of this phantom island is now named Emerald Basin.

myths.name: Elizabeth Island
myths.pseudonym: Port Sir Francis Drake; Elizabethides; Pactolus Bank
myths.title: L'Amerique Meridionale (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1705)
myths.title2: Copy by John Conyers of Francis Fletcher's map of Elizabeth Island, off Cape Horn (John Conyers, 1677)
myths.title3: A New & Exact Map of the Coast, Countries and Islands within ye Limits of ye South Sea Company (Herman Moll, 1726)
myths.description:
While Sir Francis Drake and his crew were rounding Cape Horn on his circumnavigation of the globe in 1578, they were blown south in a series of storms. At 57°S they encountered an island where they found shelter, remaining there for 3-4 days. The island was never found again.

The ship's chaplain gave a good description and sketch of the island, describing it as c. 30 miles north to south, almost square, and with a lake at its centre.

Cape Horn has been suggested as a possible landing place, as has Sars Bank, though this now lies a few hundred metres below sea level. Captain W.D. Burnham in 1885 thought he may have found remnants of Elizabeth Island at a position of 56°36'S 74°20'W, where he sounded depths of between 67 and 70 fathoms (c. 125 metres) and was able to bring up black sand and small rocks. Subsequent surveys have also been unable to locate this Pactolus Bank.

myths.name: Ganges Island
myths.title: Australia und Polynesia zur Ubersicht der Entdeckung und Colonisation (Karl von Spruner, 1855)
myths.description:
Also known as Nakano-Torishima (Central Bird Island), Ganges Island appeared on charts well into the 20th century, helped by the many whalers' reports of a reef or island in this vicinity. In 1907 the island was supposedly rediscovered by the Japanese businessman Teizaburō Yamada, reporting it to be rich with albatrosses and guano (phosphate). By July 1908 the Japanese government had decided to change the island's name to Nakano-Torishima and that it should be incorporated into Japanese territory.

Attempts to re-find the island in 1911, 1913, 1927 all failed, with the Japanese hydrographic vessel Mansyu sounding depths of 4,700 m in the vicinity. In 1933, a Japanese air expedition put an end to all possibilities for the island's existence.

myths.name: Los Jardines
myths.title: Maris Pacifici (quod vulgo Mar de Zur) cum regionibus circumiacentibus, insulisque in eodem passim sparsis, novissima descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1589)
myths.title2: Pacific Ocean (John Arrowsmith, 1832)
myths.description:
These two islets seemingly disappeared following several visits by Spanish captains in the 16th century, though confusion over their true coordinates allowed the islands to persist on maps as phantoms well into the 20th century.

Álvaro de Saavedra discovered these islands in 1529, naming them Los Buenos Jardines and commended the 'friendly natives'. Ruy López de Villalobos also visited the islands in 1542 on his search to uncover 'spice islands' not yet controlled by the Portuguese. Many early maps showed their location at around 10°N, and it is thus considered that Saavedra had landed on Enewetak or Bikini Atoll, part of the Marshall Islands today.

However, midway through the 18th century, the position of Los Jardines mysteriously shifted north to about 21°N, perhaps in confusion with other islands often purported around this latitude such as 'Los dos Hermanos', 'Las dos Hermanas' and 'Las dos Hermosas'. This repositioning was seemingly confirmed from another misinterpretation, with an abrupt change in ship tracks taken by Captain John Marshall in 1788 in this new northerly location taken as evidence for their rediscovery, despite no mention of land being sighted in their ship logs.

No further reliable sightings were ever made, and while searches continued well into the 20th century no islands actually exist within 200 miles of this latter position. The U.S.S. Ramapo made an echo-sounding survey in the vicinity in 1933 and did discover a deep seamount with two small peaks 1,120 fathoms (2,048 m) below the sea surface. It was not until 1973 that the International Hydrographic Bureau finally expunged Los Jardines from their records.

myths.name: Qeqertaq Avannarleq
myths.title: Qeqertaq Avannarleq (Martin Nissen, 2021)
myths.description:
For a brief time in 2021 the northernmost land in the world was considered to be the newly discovered island of Qeqertaq Avannarleq, but it was soon revealed to be just be an iceberg.

While the sighting of this rock-covered ice tricked its initial discoverers, the return of Swiss and Danish scientists during the summer of 2022 allowed more detailed surveying of the island structure to be carried out. From this work it was concluded that the 'island' was in fact an iceberg stuck fast on the seabed, covered with a layer of glacial soil and rock debris.

The name given to this small island near Greenland, measuring only 80 x 30 metres and with a peak of about 2 metres, means 'the northernmost island' in Greenlandic. However the undisputed title for the northernmost island in the world remains Kaffeklubben Ø (Coffee Club Island, or Inuit Qeqertaat in Greenlandic), lying nearer the coast at 83°39’55”N, 30°37’45”W.

myths.name: Rica de Oro/Plata
myths.title2: Carte particuliere de la Polynesie, (partie de l'Oceanie). (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1827)
myths.title: Maris Pacifici (quod vulgo Mar de Zur) cum regionibus circumiacentibus, insulisque in eodem passim sparsis, novissima descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1589)
myths.description:
The origin of these legendary islands of gold and silver most likely derives from Japanese folklore. Rumours of their existence were first heard by the Spanish pilot Francisco Gali from the Portuguese in Macao in 1582.

Finding these islands thus soon became of strategic importance for the Spanish, particularly as a potential safe harbour that their cargo-laden galleons could exploit during rough weather en route over the Pacific. This urgency increased once the isolationist foreign policy of the Japanese Tokugawa shogunate began in 1603, and which would last for the next 265 years.

Experienced explorers, including Tasman, Cook, and de Vries would search for the islands over the next few centuries. A reported sighting of Rica de Plata by Captain Crespo in 1801 helped to keep the islands on 19th century maps, with Rica de Plata lingering through onto Bartholomew's Times Survey Atlas of 1922.

myths.name: Decker Island
myths.title: South Pacific Ocean (John Bartholomew, 1922)
myths.description:
Whalers sighted land around the Hawaiian archipelago at 163°5'W - somewhere between Bird and Necker islands. While this original report (year unknown) was likely of Necker Island, its appearance and persistence on some charts at 163°5'E during the early 19th century likely stemmed from an early error misnaming the longitude from west to east.

Commander G.E. Kelknap of the USS Tuscarora found depths of 2,870 fathoms at its supposed location in 1874 after sailing within 5 miles of its supposed location.

myths.name: Jesus Island
myths.pseudonym: Isla de Jesús; Nui; Nederlandsch Eiland; Netherland Islan
myths.title: Oceanie (J. Andriveau-Goujon, 1838)
myths.description:
Centuries between sightings of this Pacific atoll led to confusion and its duplication on many charts. It was first sighted by Europeans on January 16, 1568, by the Spanish navigator Álvaro de Mendaña, who named it Isla de Jesús.

A Dutch expedition found this atoll again in 1825, naming the main island Nederlandsch Eiland (Dutch Island). Its official name today is Nui, and is one of the nine districts of the state of Tuvalu.

With mapmakers unable to confirm the true identity of Mendaña's original discovery, these discoveries would often appear in duplicate, or as 'doubtful', on 19th-century charts, with Jesus Island around 5° farther west from its true position.

myths.name: Jaquet Island
myths.title: Carte Reduite d'une Partie de l'Ocean Atlantique ou Occidental (Jacques Nicolas Bellin, 1775)
myths.description:
Charted just east of the Flemish Cap in an area of shallow waters in the North Atlantic, its name derives from the nearby Jaquet Bank near the Newfoundland coast. Belief in its existence continued into the 19th century, supported by occasional sightings.

In April 1836 the brig Seaflower of Jersey spotted it on a clear day, being half a mile long, three hundred feet high and 'definitely not an iceberg'. This observation was despite the ship making a sounding of 100 fathoms (180 metres) but finding no sea bottom. Although its existence remained uncertain, cartographers discussed it as a possible midway point for a new trans-Atlantic telegraph cable.

myths.name: Isla Verde
myths.pseudonym: Y Verdo; Insula Viridis; Green Island, Isla Verte; Isle Vert; Green Island; Green Rock
myths.title: Typus Orbis Terrarum (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.title2: Tavola 1-4 (Map of the World - composite) (Urbano Monte, 1587)
myths.title3: Composite: Chart of the World on Mercator's projection, III-IV (William Home Lizars, 1841)
myths.description:
Not to be confused with the more tropical island of Cape Verde, this neighbour of Mayda featured regularly on 16th and 17th century maps.

Its origin is uncertain though it is speculated that 'Isla Verde' became duplicated and disassociated from the real Greenland as awareness of its discovery and Nordic name became more commonplace. There is also a tradition in Celtic folklore, particularly in the Hebrides, of a 'Green Island' - a verdant land located far to the west.

By the early 19th century the island had been relegated to the status of 'Green Rock'. A supposed sighting by Captain Coombs of the ship Pallas appears to have kept the myth alive. Coombs claimed to have pulled off some of the green herbage, or moss, which covered this rock while examining it from a ship's boat. The island was no larger than a vessel with the bottom up, being about 20 feet high above the sea.

myths.name: Isla Grande
myths.title: Map of South America (John Reid, 1796)
myths.title2: South America : Corrected from the observations communicated to the Royal Society's of London and Paris (Charles Price, 1713)
myths.description:
From 1674-5, Anthony de la Roché led a commercial voyage between Europe and South America. His notable discovery from this cruise was of South Georgia, having been blown far off course to the east while rounding Cape Horn. Later in the cruise he also discovered 'a very large and beautiful island with a good port on the east coast'.

Here they found drinking water, wood and fish and spent six days without seeing a single human being. With no longitude and only a latitude of 45°S given, the land was never found again, and disappeared from most maps around 1820.

It is believed he either mistook part of the eastern South American coast as an island, or had visited Gough Island (lying at 40°20'S and which had been previously discovered in 1505/6).

myths.name: Strait de Brouwer
myths.pseudonym: Brower's Passage; Stretto di Browers; Brouwer's Strait
myths.title: Amerique Meridionale (Nicolas Sanson, 1657)
myths.title2: L'America Meridionale (Giovanni Giacomo de Rossi, 1687)
myths.description:
The Strait de Brouwer was a briefly considered passage between islands off South America and the uncharted lands of Terra Australis further south.

While Ferdinand Magellan became the first to navigate the straits separating mainland South American and Tierra del Fuego in 1520, Cape Horn (Kaap Hoorn) was first rounded almost 100 years later in 1616 by the Dutchmen Willem Schouten and Jacob le Maire. Their route taken, known as Le Maire Strait, passed between Tierra del Fuego and the island Staten Landt (Isla de los Estados). Le Maire theorized this island was perhaps a portion of the great Southern Continent (Terra Australis) that was thought to exist in southern polar regions.

A 1643 Dutch expedition to Valdivia led by Hendrik Brouwer had intended to sail through Le Maire Strait, but was forced to drift south and east by strong winds as far as 61°59'S. Nevertheless their small fleet managed to eventually enter the Pacific Ocean, thus proving Staten Landt to be an island. This new and more southerly route, combined with the still possible existence for a Southern Continent, would become incorporated onto contemporary maps as Brouwer's Strait.

myths.name: Juan de Lisboa
myths.pseudonym: Juan de Lixboa; Y de Juan de Lisbona; Saint-Jean de Lisbonne
myths.title: Delineatio Orarum Maritimarum, Terrae vulgo Indigetatae Terra do Natal, item Sofalae, Mozambicae, & Melindae...(Jan Huygen Van Linschoten, 1596)
myths.description:
Rumours of this secret buccaneer hideout spread during the latter half of the 18th century though searches for it turned up empty. However, the island 'Jo de Lixboa' can be traced back further to the Jorge Reinel world map of 1519, one of the great early world maps to show the New World. Reinel was a Portuguese mapmaker, who helped prepare the maps used by Ferdinand Magellan during the first circumnavigation of the Earth in 1519-22.

The origin for the island is likely linked to Juan (João) de Lisboa, a Portuguese pilot who participated in numerous expeditions to South America and India, including a trip to the latter in 1518.

myths.name: Groclandt
myths.title: ova et Aucta Orbis Terrae Descriptio ad Usum Navigantium Emendate Accommodata (Gerardus Mercator, 1569)
myths.description:
Once maps began to depict Greenland for the first time c. 1427, there was little consensus on its positioning, name, size or relation with the rest of Europe. From this confusion Groclandt appeared on Mercator's famous 1569 world map, which he labels with, 'Isle of Groclant the inhabitants of which are Swedes by origin.' This placement of a separate island may have arisen from an awareness of an island located to the west of Greenland, perhaps in reference to the potential discovery of Baffin Island by Leif Erikson around the year 1000 and acknowledged in the Icelandic sagas.

The English explorer, Martin Frobisher, re-discovered Baffin Island seven years after Mercator's publication in an attempt to find a Northwest Passage. Following Robert Bylot and William Baffin's circumnavigation of Baffin Bay in 1616 chasing this same objective, Groclandt began to disappear from further maps.

myths.name: Dos Romeros
myths.pseudonym: Dos Romeiros, Romeiros dos Castelhonas; Isla de los Romeros; ysola di Pomeri
myths.title: Typus Orbis Terrarum (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.description:
The story of Dos Romeros is entwined with two real islands at 38°S: Amsterdam and St Paul. The earliest appearance of this island (presumably named for the abundant pilot fish here) can be found on the world chart of 1527 by Diogo Ribeiro, a Portuguese cartographer working for the Spanish. Its discovery in 1522 by the Spanish ship Victoria as 'a very high island' was reported 'in latitude 38°S and seems to be uninhabited, and has no trees, and is about six leagues in circumference'.

Careless transcribing by the mapmaker Gaspar Viegas in 1537 placed the island farther north at 28°S, where it would largely remain for many centuries, and even sometimes appear as a third derivation - the 'Island of Pomeri'.

This distinctively shaped volcanic island (known today as Amsterdam) was rediscovered as a new island by the Portuguese ship São Paulo in 1560 and became briefly known by the name of the 'discovering' ship. Its neighbour was reached by the Dutch vessel Zeewolf later in 1618.

Confusion over these now multiple reports of islands in the region was seemingly settled in 1633 by the Dutch captain Antony van Diemen, who sailed between the two islands on board the Nieuw Amsterdam and renamed them as they are known today: the northern one to Nieuw Amsterdams eijlandt (formerly known as Dos Romeros/S. Paulo/Pomeri) and the southern one Ste Poulo. Nevertheless, this disarray of island names would confuse mapmakers well into the 18th century.

myths.name: Agloe
myths.title: (Booklist/American Library Association/npr.org)
myths.description:
The town of Agloe in the western Catskills was the creation of Otto Lindberg and Ernest Alpens from America’s General Drafting Company. Such 'paper towns' were a common trap used by mapmakers to catch unwary plagiarists. When Agloe appeared years later on a map made by one of their competitors, they threatened to sue. However, in the intervening years, entrepreneurs had established a general store and fishing lodge at the location. This was sufficient proof in court that 'Agloe' was now in fact a real place.

The town went on to appear on various maps and travel guides during the 20th century. Although the store eventually went out of business, it can still be found on Google Maps. The town itself was removed by Google in 2014.

myths.name: Seven Cities of Gold
myths.pseudonym: Seven Cities of Cibola; Quivira; Quiuira; Septem ciuitatum patria
myths.title: Mexique, Floride, Terres Angloises, Isles Antilles (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1708)
myths.title2: Granata Nova et California (Corneille Wytfliet, 1597)
myths.description:
Mythical cities rich with gold were a mainstay driving early explorations around the globe. During the 15th century the phantom island of Antillia in the Atlantic was commonly believed to have hosted seven cities replete with riches. As more ships began to navigate across the Atlantic and Antillia faded into history, it appears the myth transferred farther west to the Americas

As early as 1530 the Spanish authorities in Mexico heard reports of the opulent 'Seven Cities of Gold' called 'Cibola' located across the desert to the north. In 1540 Coronado led more than 1000 Spanish and indigenous people from Compostela onto the Great Plains, guided by a Plains Indian informant dubbed 'The Turk'.

Although the expedition marked the first European sightings of the Grand Canyon and the Colorado River, the land Coronado found was certainly not rich with gold. It was fertile though, with '...prunes like those of Spain, and nuts and very good sweet grapes and mulberries.' Coronado named the place Quivira.

Unhappy that the expedition had failed in its quest for gold, Coronado ordered the Turk to be executed by strangulation. From Coronado's other descriptions of Quivira and its people, it is likely he had found the ancestral Wichita people. Researchers tracing Coronado's expedition point to the region between Arkansas and Kansas Rivers as the site of the ancient Indian province.

myths.name: Saint Matthew
myths.pseudonym: St Matheo; San Matteo; St Mathieu
myths.title: Africae Tabula Nova (Abraham Ortelius, 1595)
myths.description:
Located just south of the equator, this island was supposedly discovered by the Portuguese on St. Matthew's Day. Its year of discovery though remains highly unclear.

Writing in 1814, Purdy stated, "We are told, by several historic geographers, that St. Matthew is an island discovered by the Portuguese, in the year 1516, by whom it was afterwards planted; and that vessels frequently stop here some days to take in refreshments." The appearance of an archipelago called Sanmetyos on the Piri Reis map from 1513 however points to an earlier discovery.

The Portuguese chronicler António Galvão described in 1563 how St Matthew was visited by García Jofre de Loaísa in 1525, en route during what would become only the second naval expedition to cross the Pacific Ocean. On the island they found orange trees, hogs and hens, as well as Portuguese letters carved into the trees that showed the Portuguese had been there 87 years earlier - in 1428. An English translation of the same text published in 1601 updated this year to 1508, adding further confusion.

Rumours of the island's existence persisted for many centuries; Captain James Cook attempted to reach it in 1775 though unfavourable winds forced him on another route. Given the historical problems in calculating longitude at sea, St Matthew island is commonly linked to Annobón Island, which lies at the same latitude but farther east towards the coast of Equatorial Guinea.

myths.name: Aurora Islands
myths.title: Amerique Meridionale (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1875)
myths.title2: Shag Rocks
myths.description:
First reported by the Spanish merchant ship Aurora in 1762, and again in 1769, 1774, 1779 and 1790, their permanence of the Aurora Islands on future charts was ensured by the Spanish survey ship Atrevida, which confirmed their location with precision in 1794 from only 1 mile off their shore.

Although the British sailor and seal hunter James Weddell found no islands at the given coordinates in 1820, the last claimed sighting of the Aurora Islands was in 1856. Some speculate the three Aurora islands may have been confused with the Shag Rocks - six small islands 240 km west of South Georgia - the existence of which was already known to sealers before 1823. Weddell even suggested the repeated mistaken sightings were of 'ice-islands incorporated with earth'.

myths.name: Burdwood Island
myths.title: Bathymetric Map of the Antarctic (W.L.G. Joerg, 1930)
myths.description:
In November 1828, Thomas Burdwood of the British transport ship Kains, discovered a small rocky island which he named Burdwood Island. The Spanish had also reported such a rock at the same location 15 years earlier. However, these sightings are likely to be a mirage (fata morgana) of Beauchene Island, the southernmost of the Falkland Islands.

Burdwood Island gives it name to Burdwood Bank, a seafloor prominence around 200 km south of the Falkland Islands.

myths.name: Polvaro
myths.title: Carte de Indes Orientales (Pierre Du Val, 1665)
myths.description:
The earliest mention of Polvaro comes from the travels of Martin Fernandez de Figueroa, a Spanish gentleman who joined a Portuguese fleet sailing to the Indian Ocean in 1505. When the Portuguese were forced to withdraw from Malacca (Malaysia) the fleet lost two vessels, one of which broke up near Polvaro. Sightings were made of it again in 1712, 1719, 1731 and 1770, and it was described as a low, woody island, eight to ten miles long. A.G. Findlay's Sailing Directions of 1866 however concluded that it '...has long since exploded.'

One interpretation identifies Polvaro with Polu Brasse Island off the northern tip of Sumatra.

myths.name: Cloate's Island
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.title2: (8) Globo terrestre (sheet 2) (Giovanni Maria Cassini, 1790)
myths.description:
Cloate's Island was the name given to Point Cloates on the Australian mainland when it was erroneously sighted and assumed to be a separate island. The mistake can be traced back to 1719 when Captain Nash (possibly an Englishman) of the Flemish ship House of Austria spotted a ~50 km-long 'island' while en route from Ostend in Belgium to China. He named the island after one of the owners of the vessel, quite possibly an anglicisation of the Flemish surname Cloot.

A similar sighting of land was made by the ship Haeslingfield in 1743, though a difference in longitudinal distance of ~7° from the Cape of Good Hope between these two accounts meant the position of Cloate's Island remained uncertain.

This confusion led some 18th century cartographers to place the island at around 95°E - more than 1600 km from today's Point Cloates, leading to its eventual classification as a phantom island.

myths.name: George Island
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.description: George Island was characterised by several dangerous rocks within its vicinity. Together with Roque Piz, these islands are likely mistaken longitude positions for either the Seychelles of Chagos Islands.

myths.name: Roque Piz
myths.pseudonym: Isle de Roquepiz; I de Roquepires
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.description: Last reported in 1755 by the Prince George and Mary. Together with George Island, these islands are likely mistaken longitude positions for either the Seychelles of Chagos Islands.

myths.name: Ouro
myths.pseudonym: Grenville Rock; De Ouro; Owra; Ouro Rock
myths.title: Carte Particuliere d'une Partie d'Asie ou sont les Isles d'Andemaon, Ceylan, les Maldives (Alexis Hubert Jaillot, 1708)
myths.title2: Chart of the Indian Ocean (Northeast) (Aaron Arrowsmith, 1812)
myths.description:
Varying descriptions and reports for the island(s) of Ouro ('gold' in portuguese) since the 16th century left cartographers with a conundrum on where to place it, with multiple appearances often appearing on early maps.

In 1775 Alexander Dalrymple - the first Hydrographer of the British Admiralty - thought he spotted Ouro from the Grenville, being a small black rock south of Sri Lanka having 'the appearance of a shoal and breakers of small extent'.

Earlier reports include one by Captain Misnor of the Compton in 1728, who saw a land with rocks as high as a ship's main-top appearing in three hummocks. Christian Frikkius also supposedly went ashore on Ouro to maroon a troublesome man, but on a return visit Frikkius could not find him again.

myths.name: Gamo
myths.title: Mar di India (Johannes Jansson, 1650)
myths.title2: Composite: Chart of the World on Mercator's projection, III-IV (William Home Lizars, 1841)
myths.description: Already regarded as illusory in 1787, it persisted on charts well into the 19th century. The island is a possible mis-identification of Gan Island of the Haddhunmathi Atoll, north of Addu Atoll, and the largest geographical island of the Maldives. Large ruins from the historical Buddhist era can be found here, including 'Gamu Haiytheli', which was the last Buddhist temple of the Maldives. Also worth noting is the origin of the word 'Gan' is in the Sanskrit word 'Grama', meaning 'village'.

myths.name: Candu
myths.pseudonym: Candy; Camdu; Camda; Condu; Candoo; Caudu
myths.title: Carte Renuite de l'OCean Oriental ou Mer de Indes (Jaxques Nicolas Bellin, 1757)
myths.title2: Carte de Indes Orientales (Pierre Du Val, 1665)
myths.description:
Candu probably represents an early depiction or duplication of islands in the Chagos Archipelago, possibly Peros Banhos. Conflicting reports of their existence during the 18th century allowed this island group to persist on maps as a distinct group considerably east of the Chagos.

Its position often south of Adu/Addu and to the north of Diego Garcia suggests it might represent the Great Chagos Bank, from which four subaerial reefs can be found.

myths.name: Adu
myths.title: Carte de Indes Orientales (Pierre Du Val, 1665)
myths.title2: Asia (Samuel Augustus Mitchell, 1848)
myths.description:
Today the Addu Atoll (also known as Seenu Atoll) is the name given to the southernmost atoll of the Maldives. Yet on early maps the Adu Islands were mapped much further south of the equator as a separate group. This 'Adu' of old thus probably represents an early depiction or duplication of islands in the Chagos Archipelago, such as the Salomon Islands. Conflicting reports of their existence through the 18th century allowed this island group to persist on maps for many years.

For example, the islands were visited for several months in 1757 by nine sailors under the command of Captain M. Moreau. The Adu Islands were described as being 12 in number, the largest of which was not a league round. They were connected by a reef to form a circular bay, which at low water gave easy access to each island.

myths.name: Cornish Island
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.title2: Composite: Chart of the World on Mercator's projection, III-IV (William Home Lizars, 1841)
myths.description: Cornish Island was supposedly reported by Commander Watson in 1762 and subsequently charted within the vicinity of the Chagos Archipelago. It is thus possible that Cornish Island was a repeat sighting of another island, or a submerged section of the Great Chagos Bank.

myths.name: Denia
myths.title: A Correct Chart of the Terraqueous Globe; on which are Described Lines Shewing The Variations of the Magnetic Needle in the most Frequented Seas (William Mountaine and James Dodson, 1756)
myths.title2: The World, on Mercators Projection (John Arrowsmith, 1844)
myths.description:
Both Denia and Marseveen first appeared on charts from Joannes van Keulen in 1680, with the cartographer stating they had been sighted by Dutch Company ships. In all likelihood, this pair of islands is probably an early sighting and duplication of Marion and Prince Edward islands, around 1,500 km to the east.

Captain James Cook attempted to search for these islands on his second voyage in 1775, before anchoring in Table Bay to have the rigging of HMS Resolution refitted. Captain Philip Beaver also searched for them in 1812, as did Captain Veale in 1820 seeking oil and furs.

Marion and Prince Edward islands were (re)discovered on 13th January 1772 by Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne. In December of 1776 and now on his third voyage, Captain James Cook also came across the islands, unaware of their discovery by the French four years previously. The name 'Prince Edward' given by Cook is now applied to the northern island, while that of the original discoverer is applied to the other.

myths.name: Marseveen
myths.title: Wassende Graade Kaart Van alle bekende Zeekusten op den geheelen Aardbodem (Joannes van Keulen, 1680)
myths.title2: The World, on Mercators Projection (John Arrowsmith, 1844)
myths.description:
Both Denia and Marseveen first appeared on charts from Joannes van Keulen in 1680, with the cartographer stating they had been sighted by Dutch Company ships. In all likelihood, this pair of islands is probably an early sighting and duplication of Marion and Prince Edward islands, around 1,500 km to the east.

Captain James Cook attempted to search for these islands on his second voyage in 1775, before anchoring in Table Bay to have the rigging of HMS Resolution refitted. Captain Philip Beaver also searched for them in 1812, as did Captain Veale in 1820 seeking oil and furs.

Marion and Prince Edward islands were (re)discovered on 13th January 1772 by Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne. In December of 1776 and now on his third voyage, Captain James Cook also came across the islands, unaware of their discovery by the French four years previously. The name 'Prince Edward' given by Cook is now applied to the northern island, while that of the original discoverer is applied to the other.

myths.name: Nachtegal Rock
myths.pseudonym: Nightingale Island; Neklegal; Ile de Nachtegal
myths.title: Mer des Indes (Philippe Buache, 1757)
myths.description:
Given the similar latitudes with the real Nightingale Island - an active volcanic island in the Tristan da Cunha group in the South Atlantic - its positioning here in the Indian Ocean is likely a charting mistake.

The real Nightingale Island, >5000 km further west in the Tristan da Cunha island group, was originally named 'Gebrooken Eyland' (Broken island) by Jan Jacobszoon in January 1656. The phantom Nachtegal Rock was supposedly sighted by HMS Sphinx on 3rd March 1861.

myths.name: New Island
myths.pseudonym: Delisle Island, Isle Nouvelle; New Isle
myths.title: Carte d'Afrique (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1742)
myths.title2: A Correct Chart of the Terraqueous Globe; on which are Described Lines Shewing The Variations of the Magnetic Needle in the most Frequented Seas (William Mountaine and James Dodson, 1756)
myths.description: An island, bank or shoal discovered by the Dutch sometime in the early 18th century southwest of Madagascar. It persisted on nautical charts as an uncertain feature well into the 20th century.

myths.name: New South Greenland
myths.title: Morrell's track (by his own account) in the vicinity of New South Greenland (R.T. Gould, 1929)
myths.description:
'...prone to exaggeration and miscalculation, to which he frequently added a little plagiarism and a lot of fraud.'

This is one description of Benjamin Morrell, who during a sealing and exploration voyage that penetrated into uncharted waters of the Weddell Sea in 1823, claimed to have sailed along a 480 km stretch of coastline. At the time he did not consider this a new discovery, expecting this to be the east coast of the Antarctic Peninsula, the western side of which was explored two years previously by Robert Johnson and given the name New South Greenland.

However, Morrell's recorded positions placed him far to the east of the actual peninsula. Support for Morrell's claim came from a purported sighting of land by Sir James Clark Ross in 1843. But this land would not be emphatically disproved until expeditions of the early 20th century began to explore the Weddell Sea further.

One such search for Morrell's Land was undertaken by Wilhelm Filchner in 1912 when his ship Deutschland became icebound in the Weddell Sea. A sounding revealed the sea bottom was actually 1,500 m deep. Three years later and trapped in the same waters, Ernest Shackleton simlarly proved its non-existence.

myths.name: Nimrod Islands
myths.title: The Antarctic Regions (Edward Stanford, c.1914)
myths.description: This group of islands was first reported by Captain Eilbeck of the ship Nimrod who passed them at a distance while sailing across the Pacific. Shackleton, sailing aboard a different Nimrod, sounded a depth of 2,050 metres nearby in 1909. Scott's expedition on the Terra Nova also searched the area in 1913, as did the Norwegian Norvegia in 1930. It is likely Eilbeck had originally sighted a group of icebergs.

myths.name: Truls Island
myths.title: Course of the Norvegia in her search for Truls Island in 1930 (1932)
myths.description: Truls Island was reportedly seen from the whaling ship Truls in January 1930, with the height of the island stated as 33 metres. A search by the Norwegian Norvegia in October of the same year found nothing, with soundings of 4,400 metres made at the presumed coordinates.

myths.name: Baxo Ambar
myths.pseudonym: Baxo de Ambro; B. d'Ambre; Do Anbre; Ambro shoal; I. de Anbro; Isle of Amber; Amber Bank
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.description:
An island group or shoal that regularly appeared around the equator on 18th-century charts, with earlier depictions showing three distinct islands. It was reported again by the commanders of the Norfolk and Panther in May 1760 while sailing from Anjouan to India, and determined it to be 9 miles long. A final sighting of surf was made by Captain Huddart at this location in August 1803, which he presumed to be the previously described bank.

While 'baxo' derives from the Portuguese/Spanish term for 'shoal', its name may be linked to Cape d'Ambre (Cape Amber), the northernmost point of Madagascar.

myths.name: Baxos del Patram
myths.pseudonym: Baixos do Patram; Baixos de Patran; Patron Rocks; Patram Bank
myths.title: Carte reduite de l'Ocean Oriental (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1810)
myths.description:
West of the atoll of Peros Banhos, which was discovered in 1513.

While 'baxo' derives from the Portuguese/Spanish term for 'shoal', its name may be linked to Cape d'Ambre (Cape Amber), the northernmost point of Madagascar.

myths.name: Pagoda Rock
myths.title: Course of the Norvegia in her search for Pagoda Rock in 1930 (1932)
myths.description: Captain Moore of the Pagoda reported a 'large rocky islet, surmounted by a quantity of snow and ice' in 1845. Subsequent soundings made in the area in 1922, 1926 and 1931 all recorded depths well over 5,000 metres. As with many other phantom islands in the Southern Ocean, this is most likely another case of a mistaken iceberg.

myths.name: Isle Phelipeaux
myths.pseudonym: Isle Philippeaux; Isle Minong; Isle Maurepas; Isle Pontchartrain; Isle St Anne
myths.title: Carte des lacs du Canada (Jacques Nicolas Bellin, 1744)
myths.description:
Isle Phelipeaux and three other erroneous islands in Lake Superior were described by the Jesuit missionary and traveler Pierre François Xavier de Charlevoix, who was commissioned to explore French holdings in the Americas. Despite Charlevoix having never visited Lake Superior during his time in North America, these islands appeared honoring his patron Louis Phélypeaux, the Count of Maurepas. If not a complete fabrication, it is thought Isle Phelipeaux was a mistaken duplication of the real Isle Royale.

The other mistaken islands in Lake Superior, including Isles Maurepas, Pontchartrain, and St Anne are similarly thought to be duplications of Slate, Michipicoten, and Caribou islands, respectively. Charlevoix described the islands as being rich in minerals, leading to numerous failed attempts to locate the islands.

The 1783 Treaty of Paris mentioned Phelipeaux in its description of the new US border, but surveyors staking out the international border in 1820 finally determined that Isle Phelipeaux did not exist.

myths.name: Kingdom of Prester John
myths.title: Totius Africae tabula, & descriptio universalis , etiam ultra Ptolemaei limites extensa (Sebastian Münster, 1550)
myths.description:
The legend of Prester John goes back to the mid-12th century in Europe and tells of a Nestorian Christian king of enormous wealth and power - a descendent of the Three Magi that visited Jesus' crib - whose kingdom lay somewhere lost amid the pagans and Muslims in Asia.

The rise of the Mongol empire under Genghis Khan drew Christian ambassadors to Asia in search of a potential alliance for the Crusader nations. However, when the Mongol Empire collapsed and Prester John's kingdom remained undiscovered, attention turned to Ethiopia instead, which was already well known as a powerful Christian land.

By the time Ethiopian Emperor, Lebna Dengel, and the Portuguese had established diplomatic contact with each other in 1520, Prester John was the unofficial name by which Europeans referred to the Emperor.

European academics of the 17th century began to prove that no such lineage connected Prester John to the Ethiopian monarchs, and the search for the fabled king gradually ceased. Despite being consigned to lore, Prester John continued to inspire writers ranging from William Shakespeare through to the modern Marvel and DC comics.

myths.name: Podesta
myths.title: Pacific Ocean and Bordering Lands (Rand McNally and Company, 1924)
myths.description: Podesta was reported by the Italian captain, Pinocchio, 900 nautical miles off the Chilean coast, and named it after his vessel Barone Podestà. With only a circumference of just under a kilometre, it has not been found again. Currently the micronation of the Republic of Rino Island claims 'sovereignty' over Podesta Island.

myths.name: Yosemite Rock
myths.title: Pacific Ocean and Bordering Lands (Rand McNally and Company, 1924)
myths.description: Yosemite Rock was reported in 1903 about 290 km northwest of Mas Afuera Island, described as a white rock of some length with sharp pointed heads on its southeast side and 10 to 15 feet high. Searches in 1904 and 1909 by Chilean government vessels failed to find the rock again. Yosemite Rock is one of the many phantom islands in the eastern Pacific claimed by the Republic of Rino Island.

myths.name: Minnehaha Rock
myths.title: Pacific Ocean and Bordering Lands (Rand McNally and Company, 1924)
myths.description:
This supposed rock was reported in 1879 by Captain Beckwith of the ship Victoria, about 110 km northwest of Sala y Gómez Island. Despite never being found again, it remained on charts as a warning to navigators in case it actually did exist.

The name derives from a fictional Native American woman who appears in the poem 'The Song of Hiawatha' written by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow in 1855. Minnehaha Rock is one of the many phantom islands in the eastern Pacific claimed by the Republic of Rino Island.

myths.name: Emily Rock
myths.title: Pacific Ocean and Bordering Lands (Rand McNally and Company, 1924)
myths.description:
This small rock, described as being only 15 feet tall and 120 feet long, was reported by the Emily in 1869. In 1873 the Merchant Marine Magazine stated it had been seen by two further vessels, which described it as consisting of a sandy volcanic stone.

Its supposed position is close to the Zasosov seamount, one of the main prominences of the underwater cordon of Sala y Gómez. The top of the Zasasov seamount is found at a depth of 100 metres below sea level. Emily Rock is one of the many phantom islands in the eastern Pacific claimed by the Republic of Rino Island.

myths.name: Royal Company's Islands
myths.title: Süd-Polar-Karte (1912, A. Petermann)
myths.description: These islands were first reported by the ship Rafaelo of the 'Spanish Royal Company of the Philippine Islands' whilst voyaging from the Cape of Good Hope to the Philippines in 1776. The islands' position on maps continued to change as navigators failed to rediscover them, until in 1904 the UK Hydrographic Office finally decided to remove them from all Admiralty charts.

myths.name: Sannikov Land
myths.title: Stanford`s General map of The World, 1922
myths.description:
The Russian merchant and explorer, Yakov Sannikov, claimed to have seen land north of Kotelny Island during the 1809-1810 cartographic expedition to the New Siberian Islands. The island was sighted once more in 1886 by Baron Eduard von Toll, who even distinguished four high mountains on it. Toll later died in 1902 trying to reach the island once again by foot over the ice floes.

A further attempt to visit the island was made in 1937 by the Soviet icebreaker Sadko, but the expedition found no trace and ultimately ended up trapped within the ice en route to help ships in distress in the Kara and Laptev seas.

Two other Russian icebreakers, Sedov and Malygin, also became inadvertently trapped by sea-ice near the New Siberian Islands during the same year. Despite the Sedov drifting to a new record northern latitude by 1939, it similarly failed to locate Sannikov Land.

Based on the presence of shallow sand shoals at its mapped location, some argue that the island was simply eroded away. It is also possible Sannikov and Toll saw a miraged image of another island, a common illusion in the High Arctic. The island has since inspired a 1973 science-fiction film Zemlya Sannikova.

myths.name: Saxemberg Island
myths.title: This map of South America, according to the newest and most exact observations (Herman Moll, 1720)
myths.description:
Saxemberg was reportedly discovered in 1670 by the Dutch merchant John Lindestz Lindeman, who described it as being low lying but with a somewhat pointed mountain in the middle. He named it in honour of a German town. While many sailors failed to find Saxemberg Island again, it was reportedly sighted in 1804, 1809, 1814 and 1816 along with its distinctive peak, though none landed. Captain Long of the sloop Columbus noted in 1809 that

'The island of Saxonburg is about four leagues in length, N. W. and S. E., and about 2½ miles in breadth. The N. W. end is a high bluff of about 70 feet, perpendicular form, and runs along to the south-east about 8 miles. You will see trees at about a mile and a half distance, and a sandy beach.'

Many of those who searched for the island in vain instead mentioned deceptive cloud formations; in 1809 Captain James Horsburgh wrote:

'About this place I have seen clouds, exactly like land, remain stationary at the horizon for a great length of time; a superficial observer might have taken a view, and asserted that it was an island.'

The infamous Benjamin Morrell (see also Byer's & Morrell's islands) also made efforts to find Saxemberg Island in 1828, though even this search was shown to be another one of his fabrications, presumably to enliven an otherwise unremarkable voyage across the South Atlantic.

myths.name: Terra Nova Islands
myths.title: Australia's Maritime Jurisdiction off the Australian Antarctic Territory (East) (Australian Government, 2010)
myths.description:
A pair of islands were spotted by the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition in 1961, and afterwards named by the 'Antarctic Names Committee of Australia' after the lead ship of Scott's British Antarctic Expedition.

The German GANOVEX V expedition planned to visit the islands and map them in 1989, but when geologists arrived at the listed coordinates via helicopter no sign of the islands could be found.

Echo sounding has since shown water depths of between 170-355 metres at the islands' purported location. Reference to these Terra Nova islands can be found in scientific literature published as late as 1998, and in 2010 were also incorporated in defining Australia's area of territorial seas around their Antarctic territory.

myths.name: Thompson Island
myths.title: Das Aufsuchen der Bouvet-Gruppe durch die Deutsche Teifsee-Expedition am Bord der Valdivia (Druck v.Wilhelm Greve, 1898)
myths.title2: S Polar Regions (Richard Andree, 1895)
myths.description:
Whaling ship captain, George Norris, first reported Thompson Island in December 1825. Three miles further southeast of this new discovery he also found three rocks, naming them The Chimneys because of their form. Just days earlier he had also landed on Bouvet Island, 72 km to the south-west, and thinking it was undiscovered named it Liverpool Island and claimed it for the British Crown.

This was 17 years after British whaler James Lindsay had already encountered Bouvet and named it Lindsay Island, also thinking it to be undiscovered due to the significant discrepancies between the longitude originally stated by its initial discoverer Pierre de Loziers Bouvet in 1739.

Thompson Island was supposedly last 'sighted' in 1893, yet its speculated disappearance sometime in the 1890s in a volcanic eruption seems unlikely given the sea depths of 2,400 metres here. The German survey ship Valdivia finally fixed the position of Bouvet accurately in 1898, though could not find Thompson Island.

myths.name: Thule
myths.title: Carta marina et descriptio septemtrionalium terrarum ac mirabilium rerum in eis contentarum diligentissime elaborata anno dni 1539 (Olaus Magnus, 1539)
myths.title2: Schonladia nuova (Girolamo Ruscelli, 1561)
myths.title3: Nova totius terrarum orbis iuxta neotericorum traditiones descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1564)
myths.description:
The island of Thule dates back to the Greek explorer Pytheas of Massalia (Marseille) who visited northern Europe around 330 BC, and represents the most northerly location mentioned in ancient Greek and Roman literature. While no contemporary accounts of his travels exist today, later descriptions have survived.

In AD 30 Strabo noted how Pytheas found this island '...six days' sail north of Britain, and near the frozen sea'. Strabo also mentions that 'the people (of Thule) live on millet and other herbs, and on fruits and roots; and where there are grain and honey, the people get their beverage, also, from them'.

Pliny the Elder also cited Pytheas' claim in AD 77: 'The farthest of all, which are known and spoke of, is Thule; in which there be no nights at all, as we have declared, about mid-summer, namely when the Sun passes through the sign Cancer; and contrariwise no days in mid-winter: and each of these times they suppose, do last six months, all day, or all night'.

The island discovered by Pytheas has often been identified as the Shetlands, Iceland, Greenland or the Norwegian island of Smøla. Though where, or if (Pytheas was described as an arch falsifier), he actually found this island remains open to debate.

myths.name: Zanara
myths.title: Tuscia (Gerard Mercator, 1589)
myths.description:
This island appeared off the Italian coastline on a 1589 map by the famous mapmaker Gerardus Mercator. Some have speculated the island since sunk into a shallow area now popular with divers.

It is more likely this island was a cartographic misunderstanding that perpetuated without any ground-truthing, with Zanara actually an alternative name for the island of Asinara northwest of Sardinia.

myths.name: Icaria
myths.title: Septentrionalium Partium Nova Tabula (Nicolo Zeno, 1561)
myths.title2: Composite: Tavola 1-4. (Map of the World) (Urbano Monte, 1587)
myths.description:
Icaria first appeared on the Zeno Map of 1558, which recounted the fictional voyage of the Zeno brothers in the 1390s under the command of the King of Frisland named Zichmni. West of Frisland Antonio Zeno and King Zichmni encountered Icaria where the inhabitants made it clear that visitors were not welcome and that they would defend the island to the last man if need be. They sailed along the island looking for a place to make landfall, but the inhabitants still chased them and Zichmni abandoned the effort.

Most historians regard the Zeno Map and accompanying narrative as a hoax, perpetrated to make a retroactive claim for Venice as having discovered the New World before Christopher Columbus. Some have also suggested that Icaria (or Caria Island) may be a misplaced St. Kilda, or Kerry on the west coast of Ireland.

myths.name: Neome
myths.title: Septentrionalium Partium Nova Tabula (Nicolo Zeno, 1561)
myths.description: One of the many destinations of the Zeno brothers during their speculative voyage around the North Atlantic in the 1390s. It has been tentatively suggested that Neome is representative of Fair Isle or Foula, both islands in Shetland, northern Scotland.

myths.name: Middle Island
myths.title: 1822 chart of the South Shetland Islands and South Orkney Islands (George Powell, 1822)
myths.title2: Patagonia, S. Shetlands, S. Orkneys (Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge, 1838)
myths.description:
The South Shetland Islands, the first discovery south of 60°S, were quickly exploited by sealers during the 1820s. Troubled with fog and ice, the charts the sealers produced for the British Admiralty were of varying accuracy.

One error that slipped through was Husons Island, first appearing on the Smith-Goddard chart of 1822, and which was subsequently included as Middle Island on Powell's compilation chart of the same year.

myths.name: Cassiterides
myths.title: Britannicae Insulae (Nicholas Sanson, 1697)
myths.title2: Tabula II Europae (Lorenz Fries, 1525)
myths.description:
The ancient Greeks knew of the Cassiterides only as a source of tin and lead, with the secrets of the tin trade otherwise kept guarded by the seamen of Gades (Cadiz). Ptolemy mentioned them, suggesting they made up ten small islands in northwest Iberia far off the coast and arranged symbolically as a ring. The ambiguous location of these islands thus morphed into a partly mythologized generic name for sources of tin beyond the Mediterranean in the far West.

Later, when the West was better explored, it was found that tin actually came from two regions: Galicia, in the northwest of the Iberia, and Devon and Cornwall in southwest England. The Isles of Scilly thus became a candidate for the legendary Cassiterides, although no tin is found there today.

Modern-day attempts to locate these islands suggest they may have been situated off the coast of Brittany, between Paimboeuf and St Nazaire - a region that has now silted up to form the marshes of the Brière.

myths.name: Daculi
myths.title: Part of the 1367 Pizigani portolan chart. Compilation from A3 photocopies from Jomard facsimile of 1849 (Edme François Jomard, 1849)
myths.description: Along with other legendary phantom islands, Daculi appeared on the very earliest charts from the 14th century onwards. On Pareto's 1455 map of Europe the legend of Daculi (Insuldacr) is expanded, stating that the island offers a certain aid in childbearing for women carried there from the inner island of Bra (Barra). It is thus possible Daculi was an early depiction of St Kilda.

myths.name: Walker's Island
myths.title: Carte particuliere de la Polynesie, (partie de l'Oceanie). (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1827)
myths.title2: Oceania (Keith Johnston, 1861). Walker's Island is located just below the map legend.
myths.description: Reported by Captain Walker in 1814, stated to be small, low and well-wooded. Most likely this island was an early sighting of Fanning Atoll (Tabuaeran)

myths.name: Fonseca
myths.pseudonym: San Bernardo; San Bernaldo; Ysla Fonte Seca; Foncequa; Fonzeca; Galissionière's Rock
myths.title: Vera Totius Expeditionis Nauticae (Jodocus Hondius, 1595)
myths.title2: Carte D'Amerique (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1722)
myths.description:
In the 1630s, a group of Puritans led by John Pym established plans to help settlers of the Massachusetts Bay Colony disaffected by the North American climate to settle in the more pleasant region of the Caribbean. The island of Fonseca was initially chosen, but since it could not be found, they instead sailed to Providencia Island and founded a settlement there.

The name 'Ysla de Fonte Seca' (Island of the Dry Fountain) first appears on Hondius' world map in 1595, northeast of the Orinoco delta. Though it was previously known as 'San Bernardo', appearing as early as 1544 on the world map drawn by Sebastian Cabot.

Shrouded in mystery, fictional accounts of the island's discovery surfaced late in the 17th century, with one describing it as a colony of Welsh Amazon women who worshipped the moon.
