A second described it as a foul and immoral hellhole where rampant drinking, gambling and promiscuity were encouraged.

Various hypotheses have been put forward for the fancied existence of Fonseca, including discoloured waters discharged from the Orinoco, and poor longitudinal positioning of early Spanish discoveries in the Lesser Antilles. Soundings taken in 1852 by the American brig Dolphin revealed water depths of 4700 m, conclusively ending the Fonseca myth.

myths.name: Croker Mountains
myths.title2: Lancaster Sound, as seen from H.M.S. Isabella at 3P.M. August 31st 1818 (John Ross, 1819)
myths.title: A General Chart Shewing the Track and Discoveries of H.M. Ships Isabella & Alexander to Davis's Straits and Baffins Bay in an attempt to discover a passage into the Pacific Ocean (John Ross, 1819)
myths.description:
The mis-sighting of the Croker Mountains represents probably one of the most significant mistakes made in the race to find a Northwest Passage during the 19th century.

Despite heavy sea-ice in 1818, John Ross managed to reach Lancaster Sound in the far northwest of Baffin Bay (which Baffin had found 200 years earlier). After several miles of sailing between Devon Island and Baffin Island, Ross looked out and saw a mountain range blocking any possible progress westwards. He named the mountains after the First Secretary of the Admiralty, and with no further investigation or consultation with his crew he turned the ship around, despite the many protestations of his officers.

William Parry, who was on that 1818 voyage, returned the next year and emphatically dispelled the supposed mountains, making record progress in revealing a navigable route through the Canadian Arctic.

myths.name: Islands of the Satyrs
myths.title: Orbis Terrae Compendiosa Descriptio Quam ex Magna Universali (Gerhard Mercator, 1607)
myths.description:
Ptolemy's Geography, printed in 1478, placed three islands to the south and east of Malaya, roughly where Borneo should be. The ancient Greek had named these the Islands of the Satyrs, after the followers of Dionysus, god of wine and ecstasy.

Typically satyrs were portrayed as hairy half-men with tails who lived in the woods. As such Greeks and Romans applied the name 'satyr' to a large type of ape known in Africa, and in this case perhaps in reference to the orangutans of southeast Asia. By the 16th century the island group had been shifted to north of Japan.

myths.name: Taprobana
myths.title: Typus orbis descriptione Ptolemaei (Lorenz Fries, 1541)
myths.title2: Taprobana Insula (Sebastian Munster, 1572)
myths.description:
The island of Taprobana was known to the ancient Greeks as an abundant source of spices, pearls and gold, with a location somewhere in the Indian Ocean.

The first description of Taprobana by Europeans dates back to 290 BC, by the Greek explorer Megasthenes, and was incorporated into Ptolemy's Geography. Many legends were subsequently written about the island. These included reports of ants as large as mastiffs that harvested gold, and inhabitants known as the Sciapodes that had one giant foot that could be used to shade themselves from the noon sun.

Ancient Sri Lankan chronicles describe a kingdom named Tambapanni. According to the chronicles Prince Vijaya landed on an island named Lanka after he was exiled from India. Prince Vijaya ruled the island from 543 BC to 505 BC and named it Tambapanni. It is thus theorized that the name Taprobana was a Greek or Roman alteration of Tambapanni, and that the Taprobana known to the ancient Greeks is thus most certainly Sri Lanka. However, for a brief time in the 16th century some mapmakers mis-associated the name instead with Sumatra.

myths.name: Drogeo
myths.title: Septentrionalium Regionum Descrip. (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.description:
The island of Drogeo first appeared on the Zeno Map, recounting the fictional voyage of the Zeno brothers in the 1390s. While on Frisland Antonio Zeno ran into a group of fishermen that had spent 25 years away in lands far to the west called Estotiland and Drogeo. Estotiland was described as very fertile and had mountains inland. The king of this country possessed books written in Latin, though he did not understand them.

This king had persuaded the fishermen to visit another land to the south called Drogeo, though they found only strange beasts and cannibals, from whom they escaped only after teaching them how to fish. Zichmi, the king of Frisland, ordered Antonio Zeno to find these new lands, though he discovered only Icaria instead.

While the Zeno account is now considered a fabrication, the supposed country of Estotiland was commonly placed in the area of Labrador on maps until c. 1660. Drogeo was charted as a separate island, and conceivably could have been an early depiction of Nova Scotia or the island of Newfoundland.

myths.name: Pepys Island
myths.title: A New & Exact Map of the Coast, Countries and Islands within ye Limits of ye South Sea Company (Herman Moll, 1726)
myths.description:
The buccaneer commander Ambrose Cowley first described this island in 1684. However, the name given appears to have been an editorial embellishment added when Cowley's diary was later published by William Hacke, seemingly in an attempt to flatter the then Chief Secretary of the British Admiralty, Samuel Pepys. It was not until the 1780s when Cowley's original manuscripts were rediscovered that the mistake was noticed.

Confusion over the island didn't end there though. William Dampier, who was on the same ship as Cowley in 1684, published his own account of the voyage in 1697. As well as adjusting Cowley's coordinates of the discovered islands by 4 degrees, he wrote: 'January the 28th (1683-4) we made the Sebald de Weerts. They are three rocky barren Islands without any tree, only some bushes growing on them'.

Today, the 'Sebald de Weerts' are known as the Falkland Islands, found further south. These mistakes were overlooked for decades, and many explorers, including Captain Cook, made attempts to locate Pepys Island during the route most European ships took to enter the Pacific.

myths.name: Niger River
myths.title: Africae Tabula Nova (Abraham Ortelius, 1595)
myths.title2: L'Afrique dressée sur les observations de Mrs. de l'Academie Royal des Sciences, et quelques autres, & sur les memoires les plus recens (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1730)
myths.description:
Since the mid-16th century the Niger River was commonly shown to flow in its opposite direction from east to west, connecting to the Senegal and Gambia rivers, and with a source (Lac Niger) somewhere deep in central Africa. In some instances it is also depicted as flowing underground for 60 miles before emerging in Lake Borno, or being connected to the Nile, borrowing from ideas written by Pliny.

In reality, the Niger River flows eastwards from the Guinea Highlands in West Africa before curving south and emptying in the Gulf of Guinea.

The notion of a 'Nigir' river extends far back to the classical writings of Ptolemy, who mentions this as one of two rivers in the Sahara. Yet, as with all early maps of the African continent, a lack of accurate information on its interior allowed many errors to perpetuate. That the third-longest river in Africa flowed in a reverse direction is one particularly egregious example.

By the mid-18th century the source of the Niger was becoming more accurately depicted, with the river flowing in the correct direction at least but with an unknown outlet. It would not be until 1830 that its geography would be confirmed to Europeans, when Richard Lander and his brother became the first to follow the course of the Niger to the ocean.

myths.name: Lago de los Xarayes
myths.title: Paraguay o Prov. De Rio De La Plata cum regionibus adiacentibus Tucuman et Sta. Cruz De la Sierra (Willem Blaeu, 1642)
myths.description:
Early explorations of the Paraguay River and the discovery of the vast Pantanal floodplain soon led to the embellishment of a vast inland sea - La Laguna de los Xarayes. The Xaraies - translated to 'owners of the river' - were an indigenous people occupying what is today parts of Brazil's Matte Grosso and the Pantanal.

To its north lay the Puerto de los Reyes, considered to be a gateway to the Amazon and the legendary city of gold, El Dorado. It was only by the mid 18th century that this mythical lake was finally busted, and later still before people realized that the Paraguay River did not connect with the Amazon basin.

myths.name: Sarah Ann Island
myths.title: Oceania (Keith Johnston, 1861). Sarah Anne Island is located just below the map legend.
myths.description:
On March 8, 1859, the New York Tribune published a list of Pacific islands that had recently become 'property of citizens of the United States'. Among them was Sarah Anne Island (4°0'N, 154°22'W), claimed by the United States Guano Company under the Guano Islands Act of 1856. This law enabled any US citizen to take possession of unclaimed and uninhabited islands containing guano deposits.

With its rich nitrogen and phosphates, guano was not just a resource, but a potential goldmine. It could be used to produce highly profitable agricultural fertilisers, and it was a source of saltpeter for gunpowder. The Guano Islands Act led to the US gaining control of around 94 islands. By 1903, 66 of these islands were recognised as territories of the US.

A 1933 review of the Guano Islands Act claims found no evidence that the island was ever mined. Furthermore, the report noted that no island could be found at the reported coordinates of 4°0'N, 154°22'W.

Later searches, including by the US Pacific Fleet, which intended to build an observatory there to observe the solar eclipse of 1937, found nothing. At the time, it was suggested that the island had sunk. Yet a more rational explanation is that Sarah Ann Island was, in fact, the very real Malden Island at almost identical coordinates in the southern hemisphere, sighted and named by the whaler Sarah Ann around 1825. Its migration north of the equator first appears on an 1836 map by J.W. Norrie, presumably due to a misreading of its original coordinates.

myths.name: María de Lajara
myths.pseudonym: Donna Maria Laxara; Maria de Laxara; Maria Laxar; Maria la Garta; Nostra Señora de la Gorta
myths.title: Hemisphere Occidental Dresse en 1720 pour l'usage particulier du Roy sur les Observations Astronomiques et Geographiques (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1724)
myths.title2: Pacific Ocean including Oceania (Samuel Augustus Mitchell, 1859)
myths.description:
An account published in 1699 reported that while sailing from Manila to New Spain, and not having the patience to endure the inconveniences of the passage any longer, María de la Jara threw herself into the sea. An island near this point was named after this young Spanish woman, though it has not been found since.

It is possible this phantom island could have originally been attributed to one of the Bonin Islands, with the longitude later mistakenly moved to 140° west of Greenwich rather than east.

myths.name: Pousland
myths.title: Composite: Nos. 76-77. Polynesien und Der Grosse Ocean (Adolf Stieler, 1875)
myths.description: In November 1853 Captain Pousland of the ship Manlius reported this reef of rocks awash with constant breakers, extending for 30-100 metres.

myths.name: Diego Alvares
myths.pseudonym: Ilha de Gonçalo Álvares; Diego Alvarez; Diego Island; Gough Island
myths.title: Chart containing the greater part of the South Sea to the South of the Line (Thomas Jeffreys, 1776)
myths.title2: Composite: Chart of the World on Mercator's projection, III-IV (William Home Lizars, 1841)
myths.description:
The real 'Gough Island' and 'Diego Alvares' are actually one and the same, though a positioning error led to them being charted in duplicate for over a century.

The island was initially named 'Ilha de Gonçalo Álvaresæ' on Portuguese maps, after its discoverer in 1505. However, misreadings of 'Is de Go Alvarez' are a likely reason for its subsequent translation to 'Diego Alvares' on later maps.

Charles Gough 'rediscovered' the island on March 3 1732, thinking it was a new find, though incorrectly placed this new 'Gough's Island' 400 miles to the east of Diego Alvares.

It would be many decades until cartographers realised the mistake. Despite the priority of the Portuguese discovery, and the greater accuracy of the position given by them, 'Gough's Island' became the adopted name on modern maps.

myths.name: Pilgrim's Island
myths.title: Australien (Karl Sohr, 1847)
myths.description: Sighted by Captain Delana in 1832, a subsequent search in June 1843 revealed nothing. A further search in 1874 by Captain Juan E. Lopez also found no potential dangers at this location.

myths.name: Gray Island
myths.title: Oceania, or Islands in the Pacific Ocean (A. Fullarton & Co, 1872)
myths.description:
The origin of this island is unknown, appearing on few 19th-century charts, though an early reference to this island can be found in 'The New American Practical Navigator' published in 1807. A possible connection exists to Captain Robert Gray, who completed the first American circumnavigation of the world in 1790.

Two reported positions for this island were investigated by Captain Juan E. Lopez, commanding the Chilean corvette O' Higgins in 1874, though no evidence for it was ever found.

myths.name: Gynn's Rocks
myths.title: A New Chart of The Pacific Ocean (southern sheet) (J.W. Norie, 1836)
myths.description: Who Gynn was, or when they discovered these rocks, is unknown, though they appear on some Pacific charts near Sala Y Gomez in the early 19th century.

myths.name: Waihou
myths.title: Pacific Ocean (Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge, 1840)
myths.description:
One of the native names for Easter Island that Captain James Cook learnt during his visit there in 1774 was 'Whyhu'. This name would later appear as a duplicated version of Easter Island on some charts, five degrees further northward. The name derives from Vaihu, a district of the island meaning 'place of water', which was occupied by the most powerful clan in the days of Cook and La Pérouse (1774-1786).

Captain Worth of the HMS Calypso found no trace of the duplicate Waihou island when passing over its position in 1848, nor Captain Juan E. Lopez of the O' Higgins in 1874.

myths.name: Carpentaria
myths.title: Indiae Orientalis nec non Insularum Adiacentium (Nicolaes Visscher, 1690)
myths.title2: Carte reduite de la mer du Sud (Jacques Nicolas Bellin, 1764)
myths.description:
Carpentaria was a hypothesised land connection between New Guinea and Australia prior to their coastlines being fully charted. The first documented European landing in Australia was in 1606 by Willem Janzsoon of the Dutch East India Company. At the time it was thought that 'Nova Guinea' was close, or even connected, to the great unknown southern landmass, Terra Australis. Upon reaching the western coast of Cape York (south of Carpentaria), Janzsoon travelled northwards charting the Australian coastline for ~320 km, believing it to be land connected to New Guinea.

Luís Vaz de Torres had actually passed through the strait between New Guinea and Australia in 1606. However, the Spanish had suppressed his report in the hopes of maintaining power via geographic secrecy. The strait was only rediscovered by Alexander Dalrymple (the first Hydrographer of the British Admiralty) in 1762 when he was researching documents captured from the Spanish in the Philippines during the Seven Years’ War.

Cook's arrival and charting of the east coast of 'New Holland' in 1770 - the only major part of the continent having not yet been charted by the Dutch - effectively ended any further speculation of a land connection with New Guinea.

myths.name: Van Diemen's Land
myths.pseudonym: Terre de Van Diemen; Terra di Diemen
myths.title: (8) Globo terrestre (sheet 2) (Giovanni Maria Cassini, 1790)
myths.title2: Carte reduite du Globe Terrestre (Pierre Marie François Pages, 1782)
myths.description:
Van Diemen's Land was the colonial name of the island of Tasmania used by the British during the European exploration of Australia in the 19th century. Yet, its status as an island was left undetermined for more than 150 years.

Tasmania was first sighted by Europeans in 1642, by Dutch explorer Abel Tasman, who named it after the Governor-General of the Dutch East Indies at the time. As more of Australia's coast began to be charted during the following century, mapmakers became increasingly confident that Tasman's discoveries were connected to its larger neighbour.

It would not be until 1798-99 when Matthew Flinders and George Bass sailed through Bass Strait that Tasmania was definitively determined to be an island. In 1856, Van Diemen's Land was renamed Tasmania in honour of the first European to visit the island.

myths.name: Mer Glaciale
myths.title: Carte des Terres Australes Comprises entre le Tropique du Capricorne et le Pole Antarctique . . . Augmentee de diverses vues Physiques (Philippe Buache, 1754)
myths.title2: Carte Generale de la Terre ou Mappe Monde avec les Quatres Principaux Systemes (Jean Baptiste Louis Clouet, 1776)
myths.description:
Philippe Buache's vision of a continent around the South Pole was an extraordinary extrapolation from the few observations from the Southern Ocean available at the time.

One piece of evidence came in 1739 when Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier had spotted land - Cap de la Circoncision - which later became known as Bouvet Island, and was the first land to be spotted south of the 50th parallel. Bouvet was not able to land here, nor circumnavigate his discovery, so its status as an island would not be confirmed until 1808. Bouvet also noted many large tabular icebergs here between 'two and three hundred feet high and half a league to two or three leagues in circumference'.

At the other entrance to the Mer Glaciale, Buache notes similar icebergs reported by the buccaneers Sharpe and Davis in 1687, as well as the mythical Elizabeth Island discovered by Sir Francis Drake in 1578.

From these observations Buache concluded that all these icebergs must have derived from a floating ice sheet, like in the Arctic. Rather than a massive continent as had been commonly depicted on earlier maps, Buache speculated that this land was instead split in two and separated by a frozen inland sea.

Buache first presented these ideas to the Académie des Sciences in 1744, which led to much discussion amongst geographers at the time. But it was not until 1820 that the Antarctic Peninsula would be first sighted, opening up a new chapter of exploration below the Antarctic Circle.

myths.name: Davis Land
myths.title: L'Amerique Meridionale (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1705)
myths.description:
Named after the pirate, Edward Davis, whose crew sighted this land in 1687 around 3000 km off the coast of Chile. Davis made no attempt to investigate any further, more interested in continuing his voyage onwards to Cape Horn. Wafer, who was on board at the time, wrote later in 1699:

'To the Westward, about 12 Leagues by judgement, we saw a range high Land, which we took to be Islands, for there were several Partitions in the Prospect. This Land seem'd to reach about 14 or 16 Leagues in a range, and there came thence great Flocks of Fowls.'

Contemporaries suggested the land could have been coastline belonging to Terra Australis - a southern continent hypothesised to balance and stabilise the tremendous land mass of the northern hemisphere. Its location along the same latitude as the Spanish-controlled gold mines of Copiapó also sparked efforts to rediscover the island in the hope of discovering further wealth.

It is likely that Davis had sighted Easter Island, or the islands of San Ambrosio and San Felix, part of the Desventuradas group.

myths.name: Bradley Land
myths.title: Chart of segment of the western Arctic North and northwest of Grant Land (Edwin Swift Balch, 1912)
myths.description:
On his 1908 attempt to be the first to reach the North Pole, the American explorer Frederick Cook either misidentified or fabricated a sighting of land at ~85°N. Alongside two photographs he also described the land thus:

'The lower coast resembled Heiberg Island, with mountains and high valleys. The upper coast I estimated as being about one thousand feet high, flat, and covered with a thin sheet ice.'

Cook's Inuit companions later reported that the photographs were actually taken near the coast of Axel Heiberg Island. Cook named his 'discovery' after the expedition's main sponsor, John R. Bradley.

The expedition was further scrutinised, with Cook's claims of reaching the North Pol3e also heavily refuted; photographs he supposedly captured at the pole were found to be cropped pictures of Alaska taken years previously.

myths.name: Crocker Land
myths.title: The San Francisco call (July 27, 1913)
myths.description:
In 1906, Robert Peary, an American explorer and officer in the United States Navy, sighted land from the northern tip of Axel Heiberg Island during an attempt to be the first to reach the North Pole. In reality, no such land exists, and damningly his original diary for the day states, 'No land visible west of Jesup Land'. Sceptics would suggest the 'discovery' was merely to flatter his sponsor, George Crocker, and secure future funding for another attempt.

Peary was again in the Arctic in 1909, soon after a rival expedition led by Frederick Cook (see Bradley Land) the previous year, with both parties ultimately ending up in a bitter argument over who had reached the pole first. Cook's claim for not having sighted Crocker Land en route determined those backing Peary's claim to find the land and prove Cook a liar. A later search for the land in 1914 led by Donald MacMillan, Peary's former lieutenant, only found mirages and effectively dispelled the mythical land.

Peary's claim for reaching the pole was not without controversy, and although the US Congress formally recognized his achievement in 1911, a reanalysis of Peary's records in 1989 by the US National Geographic Society (also an original sponsor) concluded his expedition was within 8 km of the true pole.

myths.name: Keenan Land
myths.title: Nr. 5. Nord - Polar - Karte (Adolf Stieler, 1911)
myths.title2: North Pole Region (Alexander Gross, 1935)
myths.description:
On a foggy day sometime during the 1870s, the whaler John Keenan thought he distinctly saw land while sailing through the Beaufort Sea north of Alaska.

Whalers had long suspected possible land in this vicinity, extrapolated from similar observations made in 1849 by the English sloop, Plover. A known Inuit legend of land far to the north and east of Point Barrow also seemed to add weight to Keenan's 'discovery'.

Attempted searches for Keenan Land in 1906-08 and 1913-16 failed to reach its supposed location. Surveys by aeroplanes in 1927 and 1937 also found no land, effectively removing Keenan Land from the map.

myths.name: Plover Island
myths.title: North America (Sidney Hall, 1854)
myths.title2: North Pole Region (Alexander Gross, 1935)
myths.description:
At the same time that Herald Island was discovered by HMS Herald in 1849, Captain Kellett reported seeing 'extensive and high land' no less than 60 miles (97 km) from their ship. These high peaks were named Plover Island, after the ship that was accompanying them on their search for Sir John Franklin.

A thorough search was made for Plover island in 1855 by Commander John Rodgers of the US Navy, but no sign of it was found. Nevertheless, he also failed to see Wrangell Island despite coming within a few miles of it according to his reported astronomical observations.

The myth of Plover Island resurfaced when in 1914 the Karluk was crushed by ice and some of its crew managed to escape to nearby Wrangell Island. While waiting for rescue here, land was repeatedly seen to the east beyond Herald Island, though not always on clear days. After the land had been seen three four times and there was general agreement as to its reality, it was decided to name it 'Borden Land' after one of the expeditions sponsors.

With such convincing testimonies as to uncharted lands in this region, the mirage of Plover Island would appear on maps well into the 20th century.

myths.name: Giles Land
myths.title: Nieuwe afteekening van Het Eyland Spits-Bergen opgegeven door de Commandeurs Giles en Outger Rep, en in't Ligt gebragt et uytgegeven door Gerard van Keulen (Gerard van Keulen, 1720)
myths.title2: Physical chart of north Polar regions (John George Bartholomew, 1897)
myths.description:
In 1707, the Dutch captain Cornelis Giles discovered what is today known as Kvitøya ~100 km east of Svalbard. The island was not visited again for 170 years due to heavy pack ice in this area, and over time 'Giles Land' evolved to become an enigmatic legend amongst cartographers. Sightings of Kong Karls Land much farther south by Adolf Erik Nordenskiöld and Erik Eriksen in the mid-19th century were wrongly attributed to be Giles Land, adding confusion to its true location.

The mystification continued in the 1870s when the German cartographer August Heinrich Petermann produced several Arctic maps speculating Giles Land to lie around 81°30’N, much farther north than the real Kvitøya. So, when in 1876 the Norwegian Johan Kjeldsen rediscovered Kvitøya, the connection with Giles Land was not immediately made.

With Petermann's conjecture becoming widely accepted, numerous explorers over the following decades would go on to search for this elusive land mass. The last expedition to make a serious attempt to reach Giles Land north of Kvitøya was with the Soviet icebreaker Sadko in 1935. With no land found, the myth was finally discarded.

myths.name: Petermann Land
myths.title: North Polar Regions (Rand McNally and Company, 1912)
myths.title2: Zweite provisorische karte von Franz Joseph Land (August Petermann, 1874)
myths.description:
During the expedition in 1874 that discovered Franz Josef Land, Julius Payer reached a northernmost position on Rudolf Island from which he thought he saw two distinct lands further to the north. He named these Petermann Land and Kong Oscar Land, the former after August Petermann - a German polar researcher, and advisor to the expedition.

Petermann's views on Arctic physical geography at the time were largely theoretical and appear extremely crude in hindsight today. His hypotheses included ice-free and navigable waters across the Arctic kept open by the Gulf Stream, phantom land masses such as Giles Land, and an extended Greenland reaching across the pole to Wrangel Island. Despite his scientific missteps, he remained an influential and prominent supporter of German polar exploration.

The mapping of these non-existent islands by Payer confused Fridtjof Nansen when he and Hjalmar Johansen in 1895 struggled south on the sea ice towards Franz Josef Land after having attempted to reach the North Pole. Further proof of its non-existence came in 1914 when the Russian schooner St. Anna drifted through the assumed coordinates of the island. It was thus concluded that Payer's sightings in 1874 were the result of a mirage.

myths.name: Mountains of the Moon
myths.pseudonym: Mone Lune; Lunae Montes; Al Komri
myths.title: Universalis Tabula Iuxta Ptolemaeum (Gerard Mercator, 1578)
myths.description:
The Mountains of the Moon are almost as old a myth as maps of Africa themselves, stemming from a long-held curiosity about the source of the Nile. In 110 AD the Greco-Roman merchant, Diogenes, landed unexpectedly in Rhapta, East Africa, and travelled 25 days inland to discover two lakes and snow-covered peaks which he claimed were the sources of the Nile. The Greek geographer, Ptolemy, later used this account to produce the first maps depicting these 'Mountains of the Moon'.

The myth continued for centuries, with little information to otherwise contradict Ptolemy. The 1700 map of Africa by Guillaume de L'Isle, a cartographer known for his scientific approach, became one of the first to reject these 2nd-century interpretations and correctly identified the source of the Blue Nile in Ethiopia. The source of the White Nile was later definitively determined as Lake Victoria by Henry Morton Stanley in 1874, finally laying this myth to rest.

But which mountains had Diogenes visited? While his landing port of Rhapta is now lost, the Rwenzori Mountains between Uganda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, peaking at 5109 m, are the most probable candidate.

myths.name: Mountains of Kong
myths.title: A map shewing the progress of, discovery & improvement, in the geography of North Africa (James Rennell, 1798)
myths.title2: A new map of Africa from the latest authorities (John Cary, 1805)
myths.description:
This imaginary mountain range was charted on maps of Africa for nearly a century, stretching eastwards from West Africa near the highland source of the Niger River towards the equally legendary Central African Mountains of the Moon. Its myth was propagated after the explorations of the area by Mungo Park in 1796, which at the time was vastly undocumented.

James Rennell's 1798 map of North Africa, which accompanied Mungo Park's publication on his expedition, became the first to directly name them, after the Kingdom of Kong - a real town in the northern Ivory Coast.

Only after further explorations in the late 19th century, including those by Louis Gustave Binger, did this mountain range begin to disappear from maps, though references to them persisted well into the 20th century.

myths.name: Isle of Demons
myths.pseudonym: Isola de Demoni; Île des Démons; I. dos Demonios
myths.title: Nuova Francia (Giacomo Gastaldi, 1565)
myths.title2: Americae nova tabula (Willem Jansz Blaeu, 1635)
myths.description:
Early legends stated this isle was populated by demons and wild beasts that would torment any passing ships or explorers. 'Satanic' islands were not uncommon in the charting of the North Atlantic, and it is possible this is a relocated version of the earlier depicted Satanazes.

The island became associated with the marooning of a French noblewoman, Marguerite de La Rocque, and her lover in 1542 because of their affair discovered during their transit to the New World. Marguerite survived the ordeal, along with a child she gave birth to on the island, and would later become a schoolmistress in Nontron, France.

Local folklore indicates that the location of marooning is now known as Harrington Harbour, Quebec. The Isle of Demons largely disappeared from maps in the mid-17th century as the Newfoundland coast became better surveyed.

myths.name: Banks Island
myths.title: Map of the coast of New Zealand discovered in the years 1769 and 1770 (James Cook, 1770)
myths.description:
During his first circumnavigation of New Zealand, the British explorer Captain James Cook became the first European to sight Banks Peninsula, though he mistook it for an island. Cook described the land as 'of a circular figure...of a very broken uneven surface and [having] more the appearance of barrenness than fertility'.

The 'island' was named in honour of the ship's botanist, Joseph Banks. Distracted by a phantom sighting of land to the southeast, the coastline was not explored more closely. The mistake was later identified in 1809 by Captain Samuel Chase.

As late as 1843, Pegasus Bay, which is bounded to the south by Banks Peninsula, was ironically given the name 'Cook's Mistake'.

myths.name: Papus Land
myths.pseudonym: Terre des Papous; Terra de Papos; Der Papuas Land
myths.title: Isole dell' India cioe le Molucche, le Filippine e della Sonda (Giovanni Giacomo de Rossi, 1683)
myths.title2: Carta secon.a generale del'Asia (Robert Dudley, 1646)
myths.description:
Poor understanding of the coastline of New Guinea during the 18th century meant this island was often depicted incorrectly as two islands, with a separate 'Papus Land' to the west where the province of West Papua lies today.

At this time, the western half of New Guinea was administered by the Dutch remotely from the Moluccas, and it was not until 1825 that the coast was mapped by Lieutenant Commander D.H. Kolff. Three years later the Dutch would colonize western Papua.

myths.name: San Juan
myths.pseudonym: S. Joan; S. Ioari; S. Iuan; S. Jean; I. Sct Johan; St. Johns Island
myths.title: Les Isles Philippines et les Isles Ladrons (Nicolas Sanson, 1652)
myths.title2: Asia (Samuel Augustus Mitchell, 1848)
myths.description:
Around the mid-17th century an unusually large island under variations of the name 'San Juan' started to appear regularly on maps off the northeast corner of Mindanao in the Philippines. Its very first appearance, though, can be traced back to 1570 to Abraham Ortelius' map of Asia. The island is recognisable today as Siargao, the sighting of which was first recorded in 1543 by Bernardo de la Torre on board the San Juan de Letrán. De la Torre was also the first European to circumnavigate Mindanao, and in general, added a great deal to European knowledge of the Philippines.

The myth, however, also surrounds the size of the island as it started to balloon in size over the centuries, almost as large as its neighbour Mindanao in some cases. Its speculative nature was sufficient that by the start of the 19th century its existence was being marked as doubtful on some charts, or was dropped altogether. By the mid-19th century, it would still sometimes appear on charts alongside its counterpart of Surigao, though with a much diminished size.

myths.name: California (island)
myths.title: Descriptio Indiae Occidentalis per Antonium de Herrera (Michiel Colijn, 1622)
myths.title2: Paskaerte van NOVA GRANADA, en t'Eylandt CALIFORNIA (Pieter Goos, 1666)
myths.title3: Americae tam septentrionalis quam meridionalis (Adam Friedrich Zurner, 1709)
myths.description:
The long-held depiction of the Baja California peninsula detached from the mainland is perhaps the most famous cartographic error in history. Yet this myth only began to appear on maps many decades after its discovery and initial charting in 1533.

The earliest known mention of an 'Island of California' comes from a ~1510 romance novel Las sergas de Esplandián (The deeds of the Esplandián), which described an island west of the Indies, and '...very close to the side of the Terrestrial Paradise; and it is peopled by black women, without any man among them, for they live in the manner of Amazons'.

Following Hernán Cortés' conquest of Mexico he sent several expeditions out to sea during the 1530s in search of this paradise, leading Fortun Ximenez to become the first European to sight Baja California. Later in 1539, Francisco de Ulloa tracked northwards to the mouth of the Colorado River, and proved the peninsula was not an island. And so after 1541, California began to appear on maps correctly attached to the mainland.

But in 1622, the earliest surviving map of California as an island appeared by Michiel Colijn of Amsterdam - a mythical reinvention that would last through until the latter half of the 18th century. This reimagining is thought to have originated from descriptions fabricated by Friar Antonio de la Ascension that were seized from the Spanish by Dutch pirates in 1620, and which quickly landed in Dutch cartographers' hands. The misconception spread as mapmakers copied what they considered as reputable information provided by the Dutch.

In 1747 Ferdinand VI of Spain eventually issued a decree, declaring that 'California is not an island'.

myths.name: Frobisher's Strait
myths.title: M. Frobichers Scheeps Togt gedaan om de Noor 'ter antidekking van een Straat na Cataya en China (Pieter van der Aa, 1706)
myths.title2: L'Amerique Septentrionale Divisee en ses Principaux Etats (Janvier, 1762)
myths.description:
The appearance of this strait dissecting southern Greenland began appearing on maps following Sir Martin Frobisher's 1576 expedition to locate the Northwest Passage. While Frobisher's original claim that a 'strait' he had discovered divided America and Asia was quickly disputed, this left mapmakers with a quandary of where his discovery could actually fit.

The southern tip of Greenland seemed a logical choice, and one that would persist on maps for the next two hundred years, sometimes duplicated as two parallel straits. The strait Frobisher had actually discovered in 1576 is in fact the deep bay in Baffin Island that bears his name today.

Queen Elizabeth's Foreland, the first land Frobisher sighted at the entrance to his 'strait', was often transposed to East Greenland as well.

myths.name: Frisland
myths.pseudonym: Friesland; Frischlant; Frislana; Frislandia; Fixland; Freesland; Frislanda
myths.title: Septentrionalium Partium Nova Tabula (Nicolo Zeno, 1561)
myths.title3: A Map of the North-Pole and the parts Adioining (Moses Pitts, 1680)
myths.title2: Septentrionalium Regionum Descrip. (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.description:
Frisland's notoriety as a phantom island surged once it was charted on the influential Zeno Map of 1558 south of Iceland. This map and accompanying narrative recounted the wanderings of two Italian noblemen, Nicolo and Antonio Zeno, in 1380.

The story, as revealed by one of their descendents, describes how the Zeno brothers and their crew were caught in a huge storm and ended up shipwrecked on an island they called Frisland. Here they formed an alliance with the local king, Zichmni, and for the next 14 years took part in various crusades to conquer neighbouring islands.

Some scholars consider the details of this voyage, published almost 200 years after they occurred, to have been fabricated. Though this has not stopped others from speculating on the origins of Frisland.

Frisland was not a new concept in 1558 though and had regularly featured on earlier charts of the Atlantic, likely as a primitive approximation of Iceland. This theory also appears to be supported by sources that claim Frislanda (Iceland) was visited by Columbus in 1477.

The Faroe Islands have also been suggested as another alternative, with some names of the surrounding islands mentioned by Zeno (Rock Monaco, Sudero Colfo, Streme) bearing striking similarities (Rock Munk, Suderö Fjord, Strömö).

This phantom island continued to be a common fixture on maps alongside Iceland for several centuries.

myths.name: Podalida
myths.title: Septentrionalium Partium Nova Tabula (Nicolo Zeno, 1561)
myths.description: Podalida was one of many fictional islands that first appeared on the 1558 Zeno Map, which charted the supposed voyages of the Zeno brothers around the North Atlantic around 1380. It has been tentatively suggested that Podalida is a corruption of Pomona, a historical name for Mainland, the principal island of Orkney.

myths.name: Lacus Aquae Dulces
myths.pseudonym: Lake Apalachy; Apalache Lacus; Ushery Lake; Ashley Lake
myths.title: Virginia Marylandia et Carolina In America (Johann Baptist Homann, 1720)
myths.description: The story of this fictional 'Fresh Water' lake, in what is today the region of South Carolina and Georgia, derives from the initial mapping of Florida carried out by Jacques Le Moyne in the mid-16th century. The consensus from its original depiction in 1591 as the source of the May River (St Johns River today) is that Le Moyne had mapped present-day Lake George in central Florida. However, in 1606, the Hondius edition of Mercator's Atlas made the mistake of altering the route of the May River, thus transposing Lake George far to the north in Appalachia, where both incorrectly became associated with the Savannah River. This influential atlas helped the lake persist incorrectly on maps for over a century, even leading to the explorer Lederer falsely claiming to have visited it in 1669-70.

myths.name: Strait of Anian
myths.title: Americae tam septentrionalis quam meridionalis (Adam Friedrich Zurner, 1709)
myths.title2: Asia noviter delineata (Joan Blaeu, 1665)
myths.description:
In the centuries before the discovery of the Northwest Passage the allure of an Arctic shortcut to Asia fuelled numerous rumours and cartographic myths, the grandest of which was the Strait of Anian. While the opening of the true strait separating the American and Asian continents was discovered in 1728 and became known as the Bering Strait, its conception on earlier maps was entirely speculative.

Waldseemüller's 1507 world map was the first to show the Americas separated from Asia, yet the strait probably took its name from Ania, a Chinese province mentioned in a 1559 edition of Marco Polo's book describing his 13th-century travels. Giacomo Gastalid's 1561 map thus became the first to name this supposedly navigable connection between a Northwest Passage and the Pacific Ocean.

The significance attached to finding the Strait of Anian as a potential trade route allowed the myth to grow and persist on maps for hundreds of years.

myths.name: Delta of Australia
myths.title: Sketch of the coasts of Australia and the supposed Entrance of the Great River (Thomas J. Maslen, 1830)
myths.title2: Sketch of the coasts of Australia and the supposed Entrance of the Great River (Thomas J. Maslen, 1831)
myths.description:
In 1830, Thomas J. Maslen, a retired officer of the East India Company, published The Friend of Australia in which he drew his educated guess of the Australian interior that included a vast inland sea. This presumption was perhaps not unreasonable at the time. After all, following rivers inland usually led to mountains and fertile lands, and such a discovery would encourage colonial expansion efforts.

Charles Sturt was one such explorer who pursued the myth of this inland sea. Unfortunately his final expedition in 1844/5 ended with Sturt racked with scurvy and close to death. Writing in his diary, Sturt noted, 'I had no hope to whatever quarter I turned my eye – a country utterly impracticable, a creek from which it was vain to expect a supply of water…'

myths.name: Matsumai
myths.title: Geographica Nova ex Oriente Gratiosissima, Duabus Tabulis Special. contenta, quarum Una Mare Caspium, Altera Kamtzadaliam, seu Terram Jedso (Johann Homann, 1725)
myths.title2: A new & accurate map of Asia (Emanuel Bowen, 1747)
myths.description:
Today the Matsumae Peninsula is the southwest fork of the Oshima Peninsula of Hokkaidō, though during the 18th century was often mapped as a separate island.

Initial European mapping of Hokkaidō was based on almost complete ignorance while Japan remained off-limits for most foreigners until 1868. The first depiction of Matsumai/Matmanska as a separate island by Homann in 1725 thus likely arose as a misguided attempt to distinguish between the Japanese clan of Matsumae that inhabited this peninsula, and the other native Ainu people of Hokkaidō.

de Vries had 'discovered' Hokkaidō's eastern and northern shores in 1643, but many varied interpretations of the region's geography persisted through the 18th century.

For example, when Russian forces under Vladimir Alassov took control of the Kamchatka peninsula in 1697 they stumbled upon a small colony of Japanese shipwreck survivors. This led the Russians to speculate that Kamchatka was one and the same with modern-day Hokkaidō, leading to the island disappearing altogether from some contemporary maps.

myths.name: Vigiti Magna
myths.pseudonym: Vigict Magna; Monomotapa; Cumissa; Samot; Davagul
myths.title: Western Africa. Typus orarum maritimarum Guineae, Manicongo & Angole (Jan Huygen van Linschoten, 1595)
myths.description:
Vigiti Magna was the imaginary and legendary capital of the gold country Monomotapa. Its origin in southern Africa is uncertain, though it can be traced back at least to the Contarini–Rosselli map of 1506 - the first printed world map showing the New World.

The Portuguese were the first to round the Cape of Good Hope, achieved by Bartolomeu Dias in 1488 and Vasco de Gama in 1497 (also the first European to reach India by sea). Following Vasco de Gama's discovery of a well-established gold trade along the east coast of Africa between local and Muslim merchants, many maps through the 16th and 17th centuries began to depict a wealth of fictitious information about the gold-rich Kingdom of Mutapa (Monomotapa to the Portuguese), including the river Spirito Sancto and the cities of Vigiti Magna, Samot, Davagul, Cumissa, and Monomotapa itself.

By 1652 traders of the Dutch United East India Company (VOC) had established a colony on the Cape of Good Hope with the intention to support a trade route between Europe and the East. Very soon after, the VOC and Jan van Riebeek, the first Commander of the Cape, were sending regular expeditions to the interior to locate the people of Monomotapa and their reputedly rich and highly civilised cities.

In 1685, the new Commander, Simon van der Stel, himself led an expedition and reached the supposed latitude of the city of Vigiti Magna. Although he did find a great river (the Orange River) and indications of copper ore, nowhere along this line towards the Atlantic could he find any trace of gold or a city, effectively bursting the myth of Vigiti Magna.

myths.name: Terre de Jelmer
myths.title: L'Asie (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1700)
myths.description:
Terre de Jelmer was a hypothesised land bridge connecting Novaya Zemlya and the Eurasian continent at a time when large parts of the Arctic still remained unexplored. Willem Barentsz became the first person to round the northern tip of Novaya Zemlya in 1596, but in the process his ship became trapped in the sea ice and he and his crew were forced to overwinter on the island. Uncertainty of what lay beyond this limit of exploration of the Northeast Passage would confound cartographers for the next century.

Already in 1604 Ortelius speculated that the Novaya Zemlya was not in fact an island, but was instead firmly attached to the continental mainland to the east. In 1687 the name 'Jelmer Land' first appeared on a map approximately in the location of the Gyda Peninsula on the mainland today.

According to its creator, Nicolaas Witsen, the name derived from its discovery in 1664 by Captain Willem de Vlamingh. At the age of 24, de Vlamingh had sailed around the northeast hook of Novaya Zemlya down to ~74°N, where he saw all the signs of land. Some of his crew even thought land could be seen, and so the coastline was named after the ship's bosun, Cornelis Jelmersz Kok.

This Terre de Jelmer revived these older cartographic notions of a land bridge connecting northern Novaya Zemlya to the Taymyr Peninsula and was briefly re-incorporated onto maps. That was until systematic mapping of the Siberian Arctic coast from 1733-1743 by the Russian Great Northern (Second Kamchatka) Expedition greatly reduced many of the uncertainties surrounding these 'white areas' on maps.

myths.name: Riviere Longue
myths.pseudonym: Long River; Riviere Morte; River of Death
myths.title: Carte que les Gnacsitares ont Dessine sur / Carte de la Riviere Longue et de quelques Autres qui se Dechargent dans le Grand Fleuve Missisipi (Louis Armand Baron de Lahontan, 1703)
myths.description:
This enigmatic river that extended from the Mississippi was first mapped out by Baron Louis-Armand de Lom d'Arce de Lahontan in 1703, though it was likely a conflation of several neighbouring rivers.

Lahontan was not a surveyor or cartographer, but his skill with languages meant he spent much time with French troops as a translator exploring the Upper Mississippi Valley. His description of the Riviere Longue (Long River) is thus based on earlier cartography, Lahontan's firsthand observations, and descriptions he derived from indigenous peoples for the areas farther upstream.

Many have decried Lahontan's Long River as a fabrication, though closer examination of his journals suggest he may have initially followed the Minnesota River then travelled overland to meet the upper Missouri, mistaking it for the same river. If correct, this would have been a discovery made many years before that claimed by Lewis and Clark on their famous expedition between 1804-1806. Beyond Lahontan's own discoveries, the river changes name to the Riviere Morte (River of Death), the source of which appears high in the Rocky Mountains.

With the continuing despair in being unable to find a Northwest Passage, the concept of the Long River would prove a popular concept with European cartographers keen to push a viable trade route through to Far East markets.

myths.name: Willoughby's Land
myths.title: Septentrionalium terrarum descriptio (Gerhard Mercator, 1595)
myths.title2: Tabula geogr. in qua admirandae navigationis cursus et recursus designatur. (Johannes Isaksen Pontanus, 1611)
myths.description:
This land, along with Matsyn Island, was reported by Sir Hugh Willoughby in the Barents Sea during an attempt to discover the Northeast Passage, though he and his crew died before he could communicate his findings in person.

Willougby had been selected by a company of London merchants in 1553 to lead three ships in search for a sea route to the Far East. The expedition started badly with Willoughby and a second ship becoming separated in storms off northern Norway. However, the third ship under the command of Richard Chancellor continued on to discover the entrance to the White Sea. After landing at the mouth of the Dvina River, Chancellor was summoned to Moscow where he negotiated a trade agreement with Ivan the Terrible that would last 300 years.

Willoughby was never seen alive again. His journal was later recovered though which helped to piece together events after their separation. For two weeks the ships had sailed eastward until they encountered an uninhabited shoreline teeming with ducks and other birds. This was likely Gusinaya Zemlya (Goose Land) - a peninsula of Yuzhny Island, Novaya Zemlya. From here they turned back westward until they reached the Kola Peninsula. Here they were forced to overwinter, though unfortunately, no-one survived the Arctic cold.

Willoughby's Land would later be used by the English to support a claim for Spitsbergen prior to its discovery by the Dutch in 1596, though given their latitudes it seems likely Willougby's discoveries are a transposition of the two islands of Novaya Zemlya.

myths.name: Matsyn Island
myths.title: Regiones sub Polo Arctico (Willem Blaeu, 1645)
myths.title2: Tabula geogr. in qua admirandae navigationis cursus et recursus designatur. (Johannes Isaksen Pontanus, 1611)
myths.description:
During his search for the Northeast Passage in 1553, Sir Hugh Willoughby came across a group of islands in the Barents Sea. Although Willoughby did not survive this expedition, his diary was recovered and his notes were used by cartographers to speculate on what lands he had discovered.

Two new islands would appear in the Barents Sea: Matsyn Island and Willoughby's Land, though given their identical latitudes it seems likely these are a transposition of the two islands of Novaya Zemlya. Furthermore, 'Matsyn' bears a similar etymology to the Russian 'Mathuyshin' (Matthew's) - an early name for Severny Island, the northern island of Novaya Zemlya.

Three years later in 1556, Stephen Borough would become the first western European to definitively reach the southern extremity of Novaya Zemlya.

myths.name: Yucatán (island)
myths.title: Nueva Hispania tabula nova (Giacomo Gastaldi, 1548)
myths.title2: Carta universal en que se contiene todo lo que del mundo se ha descubierto fasta agora / hizola Diego Ribero cosmographo de su magestad, ano de 1529 (Diego Ribero, 1529)
myths.description: On the first printed map to focus on the southern half of the United States and Mexico, the Yucatán appears as an island. Meanwhile California is correctly depicted as a peninsula. Yucatán's connection to the mainland would be quickly rectified in Girolamo Ruscelli's map of 1561. There are clear signs though that the engraver first cut the plate to show an island, as his error was not completely erased when corrected.

myths.name: M. Sardo
myths.title: Nova Italiae Delineatio (Willem Janszoon Blaeu, 1630)
myths.description: The appearance of a mountain island in the Gulf of Taranto was a common fixture on 17th-century maps of Italy. The error is thought to originate from a mistakenly identified annotation in the 1595 Stigliola manuscript atlas of the Kingdom of Naples. Here, the M. Sardo drawn and mentioned is thought to be a reference to a real mountaintop village near the tip of Otranto - Monte Sardo - known for its visibility from the surrounding waters. However, the cartographer Giovanni Antonio Magini copied this 'island' literally into his famous 1608 wall map of Italy, from which further mapmakers did the same over the next century.

myths.name: Gunnbjörn's Skerries
myths.pseudonym: Gunnbjarnarsker; I. Gouberman; I. Goubernia; Gombar Scheer
myths.title: Tabula Islandiae Auctore Georgio Carolo Flandro (Willem Blaeu, 1648)
myths.title2: Gronlandiæ antiqvæ (Þormóður Torfason, 1706)
myths.description:
Repeated sightings of skerries (barren rocky islands) in the Denmark Strait have been attributed as mirages of Greenland's Blosseville Coast under favourable atmospheric conditions. Nevertheless, these optical illusions are intimately linked with the Norse discovery of Greenland.

They were first reported near the end of the 9th century when Gunnbjörn Ulfsson became only the second person to sail around northwest Iceland. His ship was windblown far to the west, and although he did not lose sight of Iceland, he reported seeing skerries and a glacier in the west.

Around 978, Snæbjörn Galti led an expedition of 24 people to re-find these skerries. They did find land, probably Greenland, but returned to Iceland after a harsh winter.

The widely accepted discoverer of Greenland though is Eirik the Red, as documented in the Icelandic sagas. In 982, he likewise sailed out from Iceland to seek the skerries, and ended up establishing settlements on the southwestern tip of the Greenland.

Once Greenland was discovered the skerries largely disappeared from history, only reappearing via occasional sightings, including (based on accounts written in 1625) from the mountain of Ritur in northwestern Iceland. Their disappearance, according to Ruysch's 1507 map, was from being 'completely burned up' in 1456, i.e. were destroyed by a volcanic eruption. A more realistic interpretation though is that Gunnbjörn's Skerries were a mirage image of Greenland's Blosseville Coast.

Today, Gunnbjörn Ulfsson lends his name to Gunnbjørn Fjeld - the highest mountain in Greenland and the same peak he likely saw over 1000 years ago.

myths.name: Hvitsarc
myths.pseudonym: Witsarc; Hvitserk; Hvit Sarch; Huitsarc; Hvidserken
myths.title: Carta marina et descriptio septemtrionalium terrarum ac mirabilium rerum in eis contentarum diligentissime elaborata anno dni 1539 (Olaus Magnus, 1539)
myths.title2: Europa, ad magnae Europae. (Jodocus Hondius, 1607)
myths.description:
Hvitsarc first appears on Olaus Magnus' large chart of 1539 as a rocky island in the sea between Iceland and Greenland, curiously associated with a compass. Magnus expanded on the source of the Hvitsarc myth in his 1555 book on the Northern peoples:

"Upon it lived about the year of Our Lord 1494 two notorious pirates (piratæ), Pining and Pothorst, with their accomplices, as though in defiance and contempt of all kingdoms and their forces, since, by the strict orders of the Northern kings, they had been excluded from all human society and declared outlaws for their exceedingly violent robberies and many cruel deeds against all sailors they could lay hands on, whether near or far."... "Upon the top of this very high rock the said Pining and Pothorst have constructed a compass out of a considerable circular space, with rings and lines formed of lead; thereby it was made more convenient for them, when they were bent on piracy, as they thus were informed in what direction they ought to put to sea to seek considerable plunder."

Pining and Pothorst were indeed notorious privateers, the former being in the service of Denmark as an Admiral, after which he became governor of Iceland. The island of Hvitsarc and its compass otherwise seems to be a story devised by Magnus' imagination; the real Hvítserkur is a 15 m high basalt stack that can be found along the eastern shore of the Vatnsnes peninsula, in northwest Iceland.

myths.name: Enchuyser
myths.title: Groenlandiæ Pars (Joris Carolus, 1634)
myths.title2: Typus maritimus Groenlandiæ, Islandiæ, Freti Davidis, Insulæ Iohannis Mayen et Hitlandiæ, Scotiæ et Hiberniæ litora maritima septentrionalia (Johannes Janssonius, 1659)
myths.description:
In 1617 Jorius Carolus was commissioned by the Noordsche Compagnie - a Dutch cartel in the whaling trade founded by several cities in the Netherlands - to lead a voyage of discovery with the hopes of securing new whaling rights. The mission was apparently successful, with the discovery of two new islands. The first lay between the 60-63°N and was named Nyeu Hollandt. The other he named Opdams Eylandt, located 20 Dutch miles off the east coast of Iceland at 66°N.

While 'New Holland' was likely a sighting of the east coast of Greenland, Carolus included Opdams Island on his 1634 chart, though renamed it to Enchuyser. The name change was apparently an homage to Carolus' hometown of Enkhuizen.

Enchuyser would go on to appear on several Dutch maps during the 17th century. But by the 18th century its status was downgraded to doubtful, if included at all.

If not a fabrication by Carolus, possible candidates for Enchuyser include the sandbars Hvalbakur or Færabakur, which lie significantly closer the Icelandic coast.

myths.name: New St Helena
myths.pseudonym: S. Helena Noua; I Ste. Helene la Nouvelle; N. I. St. Helene; S. Elena Nueva
myths.title: Mar di Aethiopia vulgo Oceanus Aethiopicus (Johannes Jansson, 1650)
myths.title2: Africae Accurata Tabula (Nicolaes Visscher, 1690)
myths.description: A 'New' St Helena appeared on maps for over a century. Its origin is uncertain, though it is perhaps not unlikely that the island derived from a misreading of an early inscription that incorporated the original discoverer of St Helena in 1502 - João da Nova. By misconstruing 'Nova' as 'new', combined with the poor longitudinal positioning of early seafaring discoveries, the island was allowed to persist on maps until its existence was proven otherwise. By the end of the 17th century, cartographers were already labelling its uncertain provenance on their maps.

myths.name: Isles du Trépied
myths.pseudonym: Tres Isle; Insula incognite; le Trépie
myths.title: America sive India Nova
myths.title2: Chart containing the greater part of the South Sea to the South of the Line (Thomas Jeffreys, 1776)
myths.description:
Since the early days of Spanish exploration in South America, legend spread that far out to sea, west of the Peruvian port of Hacari (Acari), lay three large islands rich in gold that had been discovered by earlier Inca explorers.

In 1567, Álvaro de Mendaña y Neira was commissioned to discover what rich islands lay between New Guinea and the American coast. His two ships left Callao (Peru) on 19 November 1567 and sailed south-west for 26 days in search of these legendary isles. Unable to find the desired treasures, they continued their course across the Pacific, and several months later discovered the Solomon Islands.

These legendary islands of gold often appeared on early maps of the Pacific, always in the same triangular configuration but without any given name apart from 'Insula incognite' (islands unknown). Some French cartographers later assigned them the name Isles du Trépied (Tripod Isles) on account of this configuration. Despite their foundation in rumour and no reported sighting, the islands persisted on maps into the 19th century.

myths.name: Lake Chiamay
myths.pseudonym: Lago de Chiamay; Lac de Chaamay; Chiammay Lacus; Chiamai Lacus; Chiang Mai; Cayamay lacus; L. Cananor Cunabete; Kia L.
myths.title: India Orientalis (Hendricus Hondius, 1623)
myths.description:
In 1554 a new map of Southeast Asia drawn by Giacomo Gastaldi was published on which 'Lago de Chiamay' appeared for the first time. It was depicted as the source of four great rivers in the region: the Irrawaddy, the Salween, the Chao Phraya, and the Brahmaputra. The origins of the lake name are unknown, but the Portuguese explorer Fernão Mendes Pinto who travelled in Thailand and Burma in the 1540s described Chiang Mai:

And in the middle of this country or kingdom, which is what it was formally, there is a big lake the natives call Cunebeté, though others call it the Chiang Mai. That lake empties into this river and three other rivers besides, that provide water for a great part of the land. The writers who have described it state that the lake measures sixty jaus in circumference with three leagues to a jau [i.e. ~1000 km in circumference], and that all around it there are many mines of silver, copper, tin and lead, which are in constant production and yield huge quantities of these metals...

The prominence of Lake Chiamay shrank on European maps as exploration of the Asian interior filtered back, particularly thanks to knowledge obtained by the Jesuits. It ultimately disappeared from new maps entirely after 1751.

myths.name: Fusang
myths.title: Carte des nouvelles découvertes entre la partie orient[a]le de l'Asie et l'occid[enta]le de l'Amérique (Philippe Buache, 1752)
myths.title2: Nuove Scoperte de' Russi al nord del Mare del Sud si nell' Asia (Antonio Zatta, 1776)
myths.description:
Did the Chinese discover America 1,000 years before Columbus? This was an ambitious hypothesis put forward in 1761 by the French scholar Joseph de Guignes, based on the supposed travels by a missionary monk named Hui Shen to the land of Fusang in the 5th century AD.

According to Hui Shen the weather there was mild, food and game abounded, and 'fusang trees' provided for daily needs. The inhabitants were highly civilized too: they had advanced technology, including silk and paper manufacturing, and well-developed social institutions.

A description of the lands visited were written in the state-sponsored history, the Liangshu, later completed in AD 635. De Guignes sources though relied on secondary texts compiled around the turn of the 14th century. Herein de Guignes calculated that the total journey from China to Fusang covered a distance of 44,000 li - a unit of distance determined from astronomical observations - that would place their final destination squarely on the west coast of North America around California.

The ideology of Fusang diminished as the Pacific northeast was explored, and with subsequent historians also heavily criticizing de Guignes work.

myths.name: De Gama's Land
myths.title: A new & accurate map of Asia (Emanuel Bowen, 1747)
myths.description:
While fleeing Macau on charges of illegal trading in 1589, João da Gama apparently sighted land northeast of Japan. His reports were initially added to early Portuguese maps as a series of small islands, but they curiously ballooned into a much larger land mass c. 1700.

Early mapping of this region around the Kuril Islands is also entwined with the discoveries by Dutch Maarten Gerritsz de Vries in 1643 of 'Staten Landt' and 'Companijs Landt', known today as Iturup and Urup, respectively. Europeans viewed these coastlines as corroboration of a potential 'Gamaland' of uncharted size. It was only after Vitus Bering's expeditions around the North Pacific between 1727-41 did more conclusive evidence confirm that the region did not host a large landmass.

myths.name: Compagnies Land
myths.pseudonym: Company's Land; Terre de la Compagnie
myths.title: Carte generale de l'Asie (Rigobert Bonne, 1781)
myths.description:
João de Gama, the grandson of Vasco de Gama, fled Macau in 1589 under charges of illegal trading. During his escape sailing across the Pacific he sighted land northeast of Japan, which would persist on contemporary maps as De Gama's Land.

Several explorers sought out this land, including Maarten Gerritsz de Vries in 1643. It was during this voyage that de Vries discovered 'Staten Landt' and 'Companijs Landt', known today as Iturup and Urup, respectively. The latter he named for the Dutch East India Company.

Mapmakers latched onto these discoveries, either exaggerating the size of Compagnies Land or conflating the island with Gamaland or Yesso (Hokkaido).

myths.name: Korea (island)
myths.title: Iaponiae insulae descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1595)
myths.title2: Exacta & Accurata Delineatio cum Orarum Maritimarum tum etjam locorum terrestrium quae in Regionibus China (Jan Huygen Van Linschoten, 1596)
myths.description:
The first map of Japan in a European atlas appeared in 1595 and curiously also included a carrot-shaped island off the coast of China: 'Corea insula'. Little was known of the Far East during the 16th century and so the insular nature of Korea was based on speculation and limited exploration. In fact, Korea's only previous mention in Europe comes from Marco Polo in the 13th century.

Two large rivers drain either side from the base of the peninsula: Yalu to the west and Tumen to the east. Early explorers who failed to fully navigate these rivers probably assumed they formed a continuous strait.

The islands of Jeju and Tsushima (south of Korea) had gained a reputation for piracy by the end of the 16th century. As such, early maps of east Asia bore many place names as warnings, including variations of 'ladrones' - derived from the Spanish and Portuguese word for 'thieves'.

myths.name: Terra Australis
myths.pseudonym: Terra Australis Incognita; Brasilia Australis; Antipodes; Province of Beach; Boeach
myths.title: Descriptio Terrae Subaustralis (Petrus Bertius, 1600)
myths.title2: Orbis Terrarum Typus De Integro Multis In Locis Emendatus auctore (Petro Plancio, 1594)
myths.description:
That the southern hemisphere should contain a giant counterweight continent is a notion that goes back to the ancient Greeks. Aristotle remarked, '..there must be a region bearing the same relation to the southern pole as the place we live in bears to our pole, it will clearly correspond in the ordering of the winds as well as in other things.' The sighting of Tierra del Fuego to the south by Ferdinand Magellan in 1520 as he rounded South America seemingly corroborated this idea. The new discoveries of New Guinea in 1528 and New Zealand in 1642 were, too, initially considered to be possible evidence for the continent.

The included protrusion of a 'Province of Beach/Boeach' from this continent in the region of New Guinea stems from mis-transcriptions of a name written by Marco Polo in his description of a journey taken by sea from China to India. Polo mistakenly described his route departing southward from Java instead of Champa (Vietnam), thus mis-locating the lands he actually visited far to the south. These included Locach (Lop Buri), which in German cursive script looks vey similar to Boeach.

James Cook's voyages of 1768-1771 and 1772-75 finally destroyed any notion of the continent through his circumnavigation of New Zealand and vast sweeps of the southern Pacific. In 1814, Matthew Flinders published A Voyage to Terra Australis which popularised arguments for dismissing the notion of a great southern continent and assigning the name instead to New Holland (Australia). The official name switch was completed in 1824 by the colonial authorities in Sydney, only four years after the frozen shores of Antarctica were sighted for the very first time in 1820.

myths.name: Kentzell's Island
myths.description:
During the mid 19th century rumours were circulating around California of a secret rookery of seals far offshore. Captain Kentzell asserted to have seen the island: 'Soundings at first gave great depths, but diminished rapidly to 9 fathoms, when through the mist an island was seen, along which I sailed 40 miles. It was covered with birds and the sea swarmed with seal and sea elephants'.

The island raised its head once more during the first official visit of a Japanese ambassador to the United States during 1859-60. During their transoceanic navigation, low land and breakers were spotted causing a brief diversion. As the weather cleared it became apparent they had been deceived. A final search organised by San Francisco merchants in 1867 found only 'discoloured water' resembling a shallow bank.

myths.name: Tuanahe
myths.title: 76. Der Grosse Ocean (Ostliches Blatt). (Adolf Stieler, 1895)
myths.description:
The case for classifying Tuanahe as a phantom island is complicated by the fact that the island was well known amongst contemporary native sailors from the Cook Islands, and that its inhabitants were visited as recently as 1842.

A first-hand account of this six-day visit, describing the land and the interactions with the natives, was reprinted later in 1916 by the Polynesian Society. However, searches in 1844 under the direction of European missionaries failed to find this island, which was supposedly 200 miles south or southwest of Rarotonga. This failure to find Tuanahe fuelled speculation that the island had been expunged by volcanic activity.

By 1875 Tuanahe had been removed from Admiralty charts of the region along with other surrounding phantoms such as New Island (a low island offering a very advantageous trade in hogs), Favorite Island, Ruruti, and Hamond (probably Balmoral Bank). Haymet Rocks, farther south and discovered in 1863 with only a few metres of water above them were suggested to be the remnants of the Tuanahe.

myths.name: Calunas Island
myths.pseudonym: Dos Colunas; Una Coluna; Las Colunas; Tres Colunas
myths.title: Americas and the Pacific (Joannes van Keulen, 1680)
myths.title2: Oceanica (Taintor Brothers & Merrill, 1874)
myths.description:
Coluna means 'column' in Portuguese, with the names Una Coluna and Dos Colunas given to the multiple islands supposedly located here. With a lack of further incoming descriptions over the centuries the islands began to evolve and unite, later becoming known simply as Las Colunas or Colunas Island.

Their persistence on maps likely stems from the fact that they fill a fairly empty space, in a region otherwise of little interest for cartographers. Several identifications have been proposed for these islands, with Sōfugan (Lot's Wife) proposed to be Una Coluna. For Dos Colunas, Tori-shima Island (formerly called Saint-Antoine Island, then Ponafidin) has been speculated, though its position is much farther east.

myths.name: Isle de Patrocinio
myths.title: Pacific Ocean (John Arrowsmith, 1832)
myths.title2: Pacific Ocean including Oceania (Samuel Augustus Mitchell, 1859)
myths.description: Patrocinio (The Isle of Protection) is an illusory island that was reported by Captain Miguel Zipiani in 1799 onboard the Spanish frigate Nuestra Senora del Pilar. When Patrocinio could not subsequently be found at the coordinates Zipiani had set down for it, it was suggested that this was probably an earlier report of the fictional Byer's Island, 'discovered' a few decades later by the American Benjamin Morrell. Later charts would often include both names for the same phantom island.

myths.name: Byer's Island
myths.title: South Pacific Ocean (John Bartholomew, 1922)
myths.description:
Benjamin Morrell had a prolific 24 hours around July 12th, 1825, spotting two islands that no-one has since been able to find. The first he named after James Byers, the owner of his ship, Tartar, though the American captain was notorious for overdramatizing his adventures.

According to his observations, the island is '...moderately elevated, and has some bushes and spots of vegetation. Is is about four miles in circumference, and has good anchorage on the west-south west side, with fifteen fathoms of water, sand and coral bottom'.

Morrell hauled north and later that day discovered Morrell's Island. Both these islands survived the culling of 123 phantom islands from Royal Navy Pacific charts in 1875 by Captain Frederick Evans, though their positions were marked as doubtful. Byer's Island was also linked to the earlier sighting of another illusory island, Patrocinio, discovered in 1799 by Spanish Captain Zipiani within the same vicinity.

myths.name: Morrell's Island
myths.title: South Pacific Ocean (John Bartholomew, 1922)
myths.description:
This phantom island is the second discovery reported in July 1825 by Benjamin Morrell, an American captain who was notorious for overdramatizing his adventures. The first was Byer's Island around 300 km to the southeast, and this second one bore many similarities. Morrell reported: 'At 10 a.m. we were close in with a small low island, covered with sea-fowl, and the shores of which were lined with sea-elephants...This island presents all the usual indications of volcanic origin.'

Despite no-one having found them since, the United States later laid claim to Morrell's discoveries and between 1907 and 1910 had the International Date Line redrawn so that they would be in the same time zone as Hawaii.

myths.name: American Group
myths.pseudonym: Bocca Perda; Roca Coral; Eclipse; Sultan; Bunker; Philadelphia; New
myths.title: USS Tacoma's 1904 survey (National Geographic Magazine, December 904)
myths.description:
This large collection of scattered islands attributed to Spanish authorities and reports by whalers appeared on many early 19th-century charts covering the shipping route between Hawaii and Panama. But it was not until 1899 that soundings made by the US Fish Commission steamer Albatross, none of which were shallower than 2,776 fathoms (5,077 m), forced the removal of these islands from official charts.

In 1902 the potential for these islands was reignited when the New York Herald claimed in a full-page spread that one of the lost islands from the group had been rediscovered by Captain Lawless. The excitement was added to by the fact that this rediscovered island may have also held survivors from the USS Levant, which had disappeared into oblivion following its departure from Honolulu in 1860. President Roosevelt directed the USS Tacoma to search the area for islands in 1904 but they found no land or castaways.

myths.name: La Desgraciada
myths.title: Typus orbis terrarum (Abraham Ortelius, 1592)
myths.title2: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.description:
A persistent feature of the 'Los Monges' Group of islands is 'La Desgraciada' - (the unlucky). One interpretation is that this group of islands was the discovery of the northern Mariana Islands in 1522 by Magellan's officer, Gonzalo Gómez de Espinosa, who unsuccessfully attempted to sail eastwards to America by way of a northern route. Under this interpretation La Desgraciada is most likely to be Agrihan, where the Spanish met with hostile Chamorros people.

Why these names did not appear on early Spanish maps may be because the Portuguse immediately seized Espinosa's ship and her charts upon their return to the Spice Islands. Gonzalo de Vigo, a deserter from this expedition, was later found in 1526 on Guam by Spanish ships sailing on the second circumnavigation of the world. Island names supplied by de Vigo thus made their way onto Spanish charts by 1544. Meanwhile, these discoveries and the names supposedly given by Espinosa in 1522 would first appear on Ortelius' world map of 1570 as a separate group, tallying with the Portuguese source material that he had used to draw his map

myths.name: Los Monges
myths.pseudonym: Los Mojas; Los Mauges; Li Monaci; Les Mouges; Les Moines; Morges
myths.title: Typus orbis terrarum (Abraham Ortelius, 1592)
myths.title2: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.description:
The very earliest maps of the Pacific emerging towards the end of the 16th century included the recent discoveries of Los Bolcanes (the Ogasawara/Bonin Islands) and La Farfana ('the orphan', or Hahajima) in 1543 by the Spanish. Further islands mapped include Los Monges, translated as 'the monks'. This was a common term applied by Spanish sailors to clusters of bird rocks or islets on account of the contrasting white-stained crests with the dark rock, suggestive of robed monks. Los Monges was also indicated by varying degrees, as one island on Flemish, English and French charts, and up to seven on those of the Portuguese and Spanish.

One interpretation is that Los Monges and its neighbours (La Vezina/Mira & La Desgraciada) were the discoveries of the northern Mariana Islands in 1522 by Magellan's officer, Gonzalo Gómez de Espinosa, who unsuccessfully attempted to sail eastwards to America by way of a northern route. Under this interpretation Los Monges is most likely to be the Maug Islands where various bird colonies can be found.

Why these names did not appear on early Spanish maps may be because the Portuguese immediately seized Espinosa's ship and her charts upon their return to the Spice Islands. Gonzalo de Vigo, a deserter from this expedition, was later found in 1526 on Guam by Spanish ships sailing on the second circumnavigation of the world. Island names supplied by de Vigo thus made their way onto Spanish charts by 1544. Meanwhile, these discoveries and the names supposedly given by Espinosa in 1522 first appeared on Ortelius' world map of 1570 as a separate group, tallying with the Portuguese source material that he had used to draw his map.

myths.name: La Vezina
myths.pseudonym: La Mesa; La Mira; La Vagina
myths.title: Asiae Nova Descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1570)
myths.title2: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.description:
Very early maps of the Pacific included 'La Vezina' (the neighbour) as part of Los Monges group, later appearing on some Spanish maps as 'La Mira' nearly always to the south of the group. 'La Mira' was not a unique name and is thought to have been used by the Spanish as a warning label for places of danger. A further deviation, 'La Mesa', first appears on the Anson chart that was copied from navigational charts seized from the Spanish galleon Nuestra Señora de Covadonga by George Anson in 1743. 'La Mesa' is thus a likely mistaken transcription of 'La Mira' by a non-Spaniard, supported by the fact that other nearby islands of Los Mojas (Los Monges) and La Disgraciada (La Desgraciada) were also misspelled.

One interpretation for the origin of La Vezina and its neighbours (Los Monges & La Desgraciada) is that they were the discoveries of the northern Mariana Islands in 1522 by Magellan's officer, Gonzalo Gómez de Espinosa, who unsuccessfully attempted to sail eastwards to America by way of a northern route. Under this interpretation La Vezina is most likely to be Asuncion Island, neighbour to Agrihan.

Why these names did not appear on early Spanish maps may be because the Portuguese immediately seized Espinosa's ship and her charts upon their return to the Spice Islands. Gonzalo de Vigo, a deserter from this expedition, was later found in 1526 on Guam by Spanish ships sailing on the second circumnavigation of the world. Island names supplied by de Vigo thus made their way onto Spanish charts by 1544. Meanwhile, these discoveries and the names supposedly given by Espinosa in 1522 first appeared on Ortelius' world map of 1570 as a separate group, tallying with the Portuguese source material that he had used to draw his map.

myths.name: Desierta and La Mira
myths.title2: Oceanica (Taintor Brothers & Merrill, 1874)
