myths.title: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.description:
These duplicate islands derive from the navigational charts seized from the Spanish galleon Nuestra Señora de Covadonga by Englishman George Anson in 1743, and survived on charts through the 19th century.

La Mira, and its misspelled derivative 'Camira', is thought to be a label denoting a warning (look out, take care), while Desierta (deserted, uninhabited) offers a more intuitive translation. These ambigous islands thus likely reflect true discoveries, though their details are lost to history. One suggestion is that the southernmost pair represent Wake Island.

myths.name: Paxaros
myths.pseudonym: Paxarus; Isla de Pasaros; Paxaras; Parraros
myths.title: Granata Nova et California (Corneille Wytfliet, 1597)
myths.title2: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.description: Isla de Paxaros can be historically shown to correspond to the Guadalupe Island, found close to the Baja California coast. Around the middle of the 18th century a second 'Paxaros' island appeared on charts, around 15° farther west off the North American coast. One reason for the confusion may stem from the release of the 1748 Anson chart, which sourced a lot of new (and phantom) information for the English when George Anson seized navigational charts from the Spanish galleon Nuestra Señora de Covadonga off the Philippines in 1743. Given the presence of Paxaros on the first map made of the California peninsula by Cornelius van Wytfliet in 1597, its location was likely already discovered by the early Spanish explorers of this coastline around 1539-1542.

myths.name: Cooper Island
myths.title: Polynesien und Der Grosse Ocean (Adolf Stieler, 1872)
myths.description: Derived from whalers' reports - potentially from wrongly transcribed coordinates of the Daitō Islands in the Eastern Hemisphere, which are at the same latitude. The island's name is sometimes conflated with another phantom, 'Copper Island', 6° farther south.

myths.name: New Baldago
myths.title: Polynesien und Der Grosse Ocean (Adolf Stieler, 1872)
myths.description: Sighted by whalers, date unknown.

myths.name: Copper Island
myths.title: Carte de l'Oceanie ou cinquieme partie du Monde (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1833)
myths.description: A phantom island reported by whalers. On German charts the island is named Kupfer.

myths.name: Henderson Island
myths.title: Oceanica (Taintor Brothers & Merrill, 1874)
myths.description:
This duplication of the real Henderson Island in the Pitcairn Island Group was placed in the northern hemisphere on some 19th-century charts.

To add further confusion, the real Henderson Island in the southern hemisphere is a rediscovery of St Juan Bautista made in 1819.

myths.name: Dragon Island
myths.title: Oceanie (Larousse, 1900)
myths.description: Reported by Captain Andrew of the bark Dragon around 1869.

myths.name: Passion Rock
myths.pseudonym: Isla de la Passion; Duncan Island; Passion Island
myths.title: Polynesien und Der Grosse Ocean (Adolf Stieler, 1872)
myths.description:
It is probable that Duncan Island and Passion Rock/Island were a misidentification of the real Clipperton Island, which lies in between these two phantoms.

English Captain Charles Duncan touched upon his namesake island in 1787, yet it is believed the real atoll was already discovered centuries before by Spaniard Álvaro de Saavedra in 1528, or perhaps even earlier by Ferdinand Magellan in 1511. The French trader and sailor Michel Dubocage rediscovered the atoll on 3rd April, 1711, naming it Passion Island since it was Good Friday. However, Dubocage did not provide accurate coordinates, leading to further confusion on subsequent charts.

myths.name: Gallego Island
myths.title2: Oceanie (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1834)
myths.title: Mar del Zur Hispanis Mare Pacificum (Johannes Jansson, 1650)
myths.description:
According to an inscription on a 1641 map by Henricus Hondius: 'Hernando Gallego, who in the year 1576 was sent by the King of Spain to explore them, affirms that there are islands from New Guinea up to the Strait of Magellan.' Hernan Gallego was the Chief Pilot who sailed with Mendaña's expedition in 1567 in search of Terra Australis. Instead they discovered the Solomon Islands, from which Gallego himself led several expeditions.

Gallego's discoveries were initially commemorated by English cartographers by a chain of large islands stretching from New Guinea towards Tierra del Fuego, tracing the previously postulated coastline of the southern supercontinent of Terra Australis. By the 1780s this island group had been reduced to a single Gallego Island west of the Galapagos Islands.

myths.name: Conversion de San Pablo
myths.pseudonym: Île de la Harpe; Harp Island; Bow Island; Hao
myths.title: Oceanie (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1834)
myths.description:
This was the first inhabited island Pedro Fernandes de Queirós discovered in 1606 on his search for Terra Australis. Its inaccurate positioning at the time, however, led to duplications of this island appearing on many 19th-century charts.

The meeting between Queirós and the native inhabitants went well, with gifts exchanged including a set of clothes for the local Chief. Queirós' crew also planted a cross to sanctify the place.

Anaa has been suggested as a possibility for this island, though Hao (in the central part of the Tuamotu Archipelago) is more likely given the description of the route Queirós took. The French explorer Louis Antoine de Bougainville later rediscovered this coral atoll in 1768 and named it 'Île de la Harpe' (Harp Island). The following year Captain Cook gave it the name Bow Island, on account of its shape.

myths.name: San Pablo
myths.pseudonym: S. Pablo; St. Paul's Island; S. Petro; Islas Infortunadas; Honden Eylandt
myths.title: Mare del Sud detto alurimenti Mare Pacifico (Vincenzo Coronelli, 1693)
myths.description:
This uninhabited island was discovered by Ferdinand Magellan on 24th January 1521, one of only two during his traverse of the whole Pacific. Its inaccurate positioning at the time, however, led to duplications of this island appearing on many 19th-century charts.

It was named San Pablo, probably in memory of a Patagonian who died during the passage and who was christened Pablo (Paul) at the point of death. The date of discovery is also near the festival of when Paul the Apostle is traditionally said to have become a Christian.

Some speculate the island found was the Puka-Puka atoll in the northeastern Tuamotu Archipelago. Together with Tiburones they were named Islas Infortunadas (Unfortunate Islands in Spanish).

Dutch explorers Jacob le Maire and Willem Schouten also landed at Puka-Puka on April 10, 1616, naming it 'Honden Eylandt' (Dog Island) on account of seeing three dogs along the coast.

myths.name: Tiburones
myths.pseudonym: Tuberones; Islas Infortunadas, Y de los Tyburones
myths.title: Mare del Sud detto alurimenti Mare Pacifico (Vincenzo Coronelli, 1693)
myths.description: Shortly after making landfall on San Pablo (Paul), on 4th February 1521 Magellan discovered another small island of a very similar nature. They named it Tiburones, on account of the numerous sharks near it. Magellan had likely discovered Flint Island, part of the Southern Line Islands under the jurisdiction of Kiribati. Together with San Pablo, they were named Islas Infortunadas (Unfortunate Islands in Spanish).

myths.name: St Juan Bautista
myths.pseudonym: St Juan Baptista; Henderson Island; Elizabeth Island
myths.title: Composite: Nos. 76-77. Polynesien und Der Grosse Ocean (Adolf Stieler, 1875)
myths.description:
This uninhabited island was discovered on 29th January 1606 by the Portuguese captain Pedro Fernandes de Queirós on his search for Terra Australis. Poor positioning of the island at the time meant cartographers did not immediately connect this with later sightings, and so the island would erroneously appear twice on 19th-century charts of the Pacific.

It was named San Juan Bautista by Queirós, and with limited options to port where they could take on wood and water, they continued on their voyage in search of Terra Australis.

Over two centuries later, Captain Henderson rediscovered the island on 17th January 1819, as did Captain Henry King in the Elizabeth only six weeks later, finding the king's colours already flying. Today this island in the Pitcairn Group retains it name of Henderson Island, though some 19th century charts placed it incorrectly in the northern hemisphere.

myths.name: Las Cuarto Coronades
myths.pseudonym: Las Cuatro Hermanas; Las Virgenes; Las Anegadas; Los Coronados; 4 crowns
myths.title: Atlas des ganzen Erdkreises (C.G. Reichard, 1803)
myths.description:
These atolls were discovered by Pedro Fernandes de Queirós during his search for Terra Australis, though confusion on their true location led to duplications of the islands appearing on subsequent charts.

The day after discovering 'St Elmo', Queirós came across 'four atolls crowned by coconut palms' on 5th February 1605. The consensus is that this is the Acteon Group - an uninhabited subgroup in the far southeast of the Tuamotu atoll group in French Polynesia.

Their rediscovery is generally credited to Thomas Ebrill, captain of the Tahitian trading vessel Amphitrite, who came across these islands in 1833. However, they were sighted by Hugh Cuming on his ship Discoverer on 14th March 1828. They were named four years later by Lord Edward Russell – commander of HMS Actaeon.

myths.name: St Elmo
myths.pseudonym: San Telmo; San Blas; Corral de Agua; Lord Hood; Marutea Sud
myths.title: Carte d'assemblage de l'Oceanique (Philippe Vandermaelen, 1827)
myths.description:
During his search for Terra Australis, Pedro Fernandes de Queirós discovered many isolated islands in the Pacific, including St Elmo. But as with many of Queirós' discoveries, they would remain alongside duplicate counterparts on many charts through to the 19th century.

Following the discoveries of Ducie (Incarnation) and Henderson (St Juan Bautista) Queirós sailed WNW and found themselves in a terrible storm. During a very fearful night on February 3rd 1606, St Elmo appeared, and when the long-wished-for daylight came, they saw it was an island surrounded by a reef. Water and wood were sought, but the island was found to be barren of both.

The island Queirós had stumbled upon was Marutea Sud, which was later explored by Edward Edwards of the Royal Navy while he was searching for the mutineers of HMS Bounty in 1791. Edwards would rename the island 'Lord Hood'.

myths.name: Britomart Island
myths.title: Polynesia, Islands of Pacific (Letts, Son & Co, 1883)
myths.description: A sighting was made of this island in 1822, but has not been seen since.

myths.name: San Miguel
myths.pseudonym: San Miguel Arcángel; Santa Polonia; Lord Egmont; Industriel; Vairaatea
myths.title: Polynesia, Islands of Pacific (Letts, Son & Co, 1883)
myths.description:
During his search for Terra Australis, Pedro Fernandes de Queirós discovered many isolated islands in the Pacific, including San Miguel. But as with many of Queirós' discoveries, they would remain alongside duplicate counterparts on many charts throughout the 19th century.

The day before discovering their first inhabited island, Queirós passed by an island they named San Miguel. An alternative name of Santa Polonia was also given as it was sighted on the day of this Christian martyr. Based on the positioning of the other islands Queirós visited in 1606, this island is most likely Vairaatea, a small atoll of the Tuamotu group in French Polynesia.

Englishman Samuel Wallis visited Vairaatea again in 1767, naming it 'Lord Egmont'. In some maps, it also appears as 'Industriel'.

myths.name: Incarnation Island
myths.pseudonym: La Encarnación; Luna Puesta; Ducie Island
myths.title: Oceanie (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1834)
myths.description:
Incarnation Island was the first of eighteen discoveries for Pedro Fernandes de Queirós in 1606 during his search for Terra Australis across the Pacific. Poor accuracy in ship positioning and confusion over multiple discoveries of this same island over the years meant that for some centuries afterwards, duplicated islands would appear together on the same charts.

Queirós originally named the island Luna Puesta ('moon that has set') when he sailed past it on January 26th. In the chart later drawn up from the expedition by Admiral José de Espinosa, this first island found was instead marked as La Encarnación.

The original description matches that of the real Ducie Island, which was later rediscovered on 16th March 1791 by Captain Edward Edwards, who named it in honour of Francis Reynolds-Moreton, 3rd Baron Ducie, under whom he had served earlier in his career.

myths.name: Norumbega
myths.title: Norumbega et Virginia (Cornielle Wytfliet, 1597). Map reproduction courtesy of the Norman B. Leventhal Map & Education Center at the Boston Public Library
myths.title2: Nova Belgica et Anglia Nova (Willem Blaeu, 1635)
myths.description:
The legendary rich city of Norumbega evolved over many decades, though its origin can be traced to the voyage of the Italian explorer, Giovanni de Verrazano, who sailed along the North American coast in 1522-4 looking for a route to the Pacific. On subsequent maps and charts made using information from this voyage a river was labelled Oranbega, the name perhaps deriving from one of the Algonquian languages spoken in 'New France' and meaning 'quiet place between the rapids' or 'quiet stretch of water'.

In 1542-3 and during Jean-François Roberval's failed attempt to colonize Canada, his pilot, Jean Alfonse, described the Cape of Norumbegue (Cape Cod), as well as the city of Norumbega some 40 miles north, 'and there is in it a good people, and they have pelts of all kinds of animals'.

By 1582, descriptions of the city of Norumbega had been further embellished, with David Ingram's account stating He saw kings decorated with rubies six inches long; and they were borne on chairs of silver and crystal, adorned with precious stones. He saw pearls as common as pebbles, and the natives were laden down by their ornaments of gold and silver. The city of Bega was three-quarters of a mile long and had many streets wider than those of London. Some houses had massive pillars of crystal and silver.'.

Attempts to find this great city by the English and French were left severely disappointed, with French cartographers assigning Norumbega to a native settlement at the mouth of the Penobscot River.

myths.name: Cyanida
myths.title: The Cosmography of Claudius Ptolemaeus the Alexandrian (Cosmographia Claudii Ptolomaei Alexandrini) (Reichenbach Monastery, 1467)
myths.title2: Geographia Ptolomey's 9th European map (Francesco Berlinghieri, 1482)
myths.description:
This sizable island in the Black Sea disappeared from maps in the 16th century. Had it really existed, or had it sunk below the waves?

Cyanida began featuring on maps during the 15th century based on a work written c. 150 AD by Greco-Roman geographer Claudius Ptolemy called Geography. It sometimes appeared as two smaller islands separated by a channel.

Some researchers have associated Cyanida with the 'Cyanean Rocks' (also known as the Symplegades), mentioned in texts written by Herodotus c. 430 BC. According to Greek mythology this pair of rocks north of the Bosphorus clashed together whenever a vessel went through. They were defeated by Jason and the Argonauts who were able to row fast enough to get through, losing only part of their stern ornament. After that, the Symplegades forever stopped their deadly movements.

The myth of Cyanida was revisited during the 1980s by Professor Dinyo Kanev, who claimed to have found evidence for a former island on the seafloor off Bulgaria's coastline. He thus inferred the island had been eroded away by waves some 500 years ago; it would certainly not have been the first to have been lost to the Black Sea.

myths.name: Manuel Rodriguez Reef
myths.pseudonym: Manuel Rodriguez Shoal; Baxo de Manuel Rodriguez; Rodrigues Bank
myths.title: A chart of the Pacific Ocean from the equinoctial to the latitude of 39 1/2 d. no. (Richard William Seale, 1748)
myths.title2: Pacific Ocean including Oceania (Samuel Augustus Mitchell, 1859)
myths.description:
The capture of secret Spanish charts by Admiral Anson in 1743 provided a treasure trove of new geographic knowledge about the Pacific for the English. The nautical charts depicted the trade routes used by Spanish galleons between Mexico and the Philippines during the previous 200 years. One such nugget of information was the Manuel Rodriguez shoal, which according to the Spanish could be found at 11°20'N, and somewhere between 141°17'W and 163°W. On new English charts it was plotted around 153°54'W.

This position was passed over by Lieut. Ringgold of the US Exploring Expedition in 1840 but no indications of it were found.

If the Spanish had originally discovered a real island is unknown - its location on the chart does not offer any obvious clues. The nearest candidate is Kingman Reef, a largely submerged reef discovered in 1798 and roughly 1000 km to the southwest.

myths.name: San Bartholomé
myths.pseudonym: Baixos de San Bartholomew; St Bartholomeo; Bartholomew Island; Bajos de Abreojo; Baxos de Villalobos
myths.title: Maris Pacifici (quod vulgo Mar de Zur) cum regionibus circumiacentibus, insulisque in eodem passim sparsis, novissima descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1589)
myths.title2: A New Chart of The Pacific Ocean (southern sheet) (J.W. Norie, 1836)
myths.description:
In 1526 Torribio de Salazar discovered the Taongi (Bokak) atoll - the northernmost outlier of the Marshalls - during a Spanish expedition looking for a route to the spice islands and for treasure. Found on St. Bartholomew's feast day it was named after the saint.

Ruy López de Villabolos found the atoll again in 1542 having been told rumours it was the source of King Solomon's legendary wealth. According to the Bible, King Solomon’s gold mines were located in the mysterious land of Ophir, yet information on where this land lay was crucially missing.

It was in the dead of night that Villabolos' fleet unexpectedly encountered the shoals, only narrowly avoiding grounding their ships. Wind and currents kept the ships moving west though, leaving the question of untold treasures for another day.

The shoals would go on to appear on many contemporary maps, with alternative names including Bajos de Abreojo (open your eyes) and Bajos de Villalobos. In 1561, Giacomo Gastaldi even drew a depiction of King Solomon standing beside the island.

While San Bartholomé is not a true phantom island, mapmakers through to the early 20th century were still untangling which islands found on historic charts were real or false. Poorly measured coordinates from historic expeditions meant San Bartholomé was often placed with a question mark on later maps, plotted adjacent to its modern counterpart, plotted with reinterpreted coordinates, or conflated with completely different islands. For example, on some maps a St. Bartholomew Island appeared at 6°35'N 148°47'E in the Caroline Islands, seemingly assumed to be Pulusuk (e.g., by Norie in 1836).

myths.name: San Pedro
myths.pseudonym: St Pierre; S. Pietro; S. Petro; Y de S. Y<sup>e</sup>; Y de S. Y<sup>o</sup>
myths.title: Maris Pacifici (quod vulgo Mar de Zur) cum regionibus circumiacentibus, insulisque in eodem passim sparsis, novissima descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1589)
myths.title2: Insulae Moluccae celeberrimæ sunt ob Maximam aromatum copiam quam per totum terrarum orbem mittunt... (Petrus Plancius, 1594)
myths.description:
San Pedro persisted on maps for over 300 years, first appearing during the age of Spanish explorations of the Pacific. Yet who or when this atoll was discovered remains an enigma.

Abraham Ortelius was the first to map this archipelago in 1587, naming it on his map of the Americas as 'Y de S. Ye'. Two years later Oretlius included the island group again on a map of the Pacific, calling it 'Y de S. Yo'.

By 1594 Plancius had renamed this distinctive ciruclar island group to I. de S. Petro and the name stuck for the next three centuries.

According to Guillaume De L'Isle the island had been discovered by Olivier van Noort in 1600. However, van Noort's only stop in the Pacific during his circumnavigation of the globe was in Guam, or Isla de los Ladrones as it had been named by Magellan in 1521.

No logs from the many Spanish galleons crossing the Pacific during the 16th century appear to have named an island San Pedro in this region either. What was Ortelius' source then?

The closest known discovery is the island of San Bartholomé in 1526. Some early maps had simply labelled this atoll with the warning 'abreojo' ('open eye' in Spanish). Had Ortelius simply misread this label from a source map when updating his 1587 map with 'Y de S. Ye'? Continuing the communication breakdown, was Ortelius' label then in turn reinterpreted as I de S. Pedro? The case remains open.

Recorded efforts to visit this island came in the 19th century. Its assumed position was passed over by Samuel Knox of the US Exploring Expedition in 1841 but no indications of it were found.

myths.name: Barbudos
myths.pseudonym: Barber; Barbadoes; Basker; Barbary; Barbera; Barlos; Barbar's; Barbudos; Bermudes; Barbados
myths.title: Insulae Moluccae celeberrimæ sunt ob Maximam aromatum copiam quam per totum terrarum orbem mittunt... (Petrus Plancius, 1594)
myths.title2: Oceanie (Conrad Malte-Brun, 1837)
myths.description:
The first recorded sighting of Mejit Island of the Marshall Islands by Europeans was by the Spanish expedition of Miguel López de Legazpi on 9 January 1565. The pilot, Esteban Rodriguez, noted, 'There were about 100 Indians at this island, comely with beards; for this reason, we named this island Los Barbudos (the Bearded Ones).

It would continue to appear on maps over the coming centuries, labelled with a variety of permeatations of its original name. By the 19th century naming had seemingly settled on Barber Island, though various unchecked sightings by whalers in this region meant the island would continue to be duplicated and misplotted into the 20th century.

myths.name: Hammet Island
myths.title: Australie (Adrien Hubert Brue, 1826)
myths.title2: World on Mercator's projection (Edward Stanford, 1904)
myths.description:
This small island was reportedly discovered by Captain Hammant of the brig Endeavour on 6 July 1817 at a position of 36°27'S, 127°2'E. It was reported as being about 30 feet high and 400 yards in circuit.

Hammant further noted they saw Kangaroo Island 3 hours later, which being 150 leagues away from this position makes the position of this discovery very doubtful.

By 1838 it was already being marked as doubtful on maps, and although its name would often morph to 'Hammet' it would go on to survive as a phantom island for almost a century.

myths.name: Albion Island
myths.title: Carte générale de la Nouvelle Hollande (Louis Claude Desaulses de Freycinet, 1811)
myths.title2: World on Mercator's projection (Edward Stanford, 1904)
myths.description:
The first appearance of Albion Island on maps coincides with a rivalry between the French and English on who would be the first to publish the first chart of Australia's full coastline.

At the start of the 19th century, maps of Australia were still incomplete. Therefore, when in 1802 the English whaling ship Albion reported a new island around 38°20'S, 139°40'E off the southern coastline, there was little information to verify or deny the claim. In fact, it corroborated another recent sighting by Robert Turnbull of the whaler Britannia on a voyage out of Port Jackson during thick fog.

During this same year, two expeditions were sailing around Australia - one French, led by Nicolas Baudin, and the other English, led by Matthew Flinders. Despite the two nations being in the midst of war, Flinders and Baudin exchanged details of their discoveries when they met in Encounter Bay. Flinders would go on to become the first person to circumnavigate Australia.

Yet this goodwill between rival nations did not last long. During Flinders' return to England, his ship required urgent repairs on the French-held island of Mauritius. Yet the French governor was suspicious of his alleged scientific mission and imprisoned Flinders on the island for six years. This detainment gave Louis de Freycinet of France sufficient time to publish in 1811 the first map of Australia showing its full coastline.

It is on this map that the rumoured Albion Island first appears, albeit nameless, off the coast of what had been named 'Terre Napoleon'. Flinders would go on to publish his own chart in 1814 - which adopted the first use of the term 'Australia' - and also included Albion Island, with the simple annotation of 'uncertain'.

Despite Albion Island being quickly disproved by Dr David Reid of the convict transport Baring in 1815, Albion Island would continue appearing on maps into the early 20th century. Newspaper reports from the 1920s suggest Albion Island was probably a mirage after a similar occurrence had been witnessed from the Great Australian Bight.

myths.name: Volunteer Island
myths.pseudonym: Starbuck Island; Coral Queen Island; Hero Island; Low Island; Starve Island
myths.title: Western Hemisphere. Eastern Hemisphere. (James Gardner, 1825)
myths.title2: The World on Mercators Projection (J.E. Chalifour, 1915)
myths.description:
Multiple sightings and names given to Starbuck Island in the early 19th century led to confusion and its duplication on contemporary maps.

James Henderson was the first to sight this low-lying island in 1819 while sailing from South America to Calcutta, India. The whaler Obed Starbuck (captaining the ship Hero) found it again in 1823, but it would be Obed's cousin, Valentine Starbuck onboard the whaler L'Aigle, who would be the first non-Pacific islander to set foot here just a few months later. Valentine named it Volunteer Island.

Captain George Anson Byron, of the British warship HMS Blonde, would chart the island in 1825. Being familiar with Valentine's sighting 2 years earlier, Byron renamed it Starbuck Island.

myths.name: St Thomas monastery
myths.pseudonym: S Thome coenobium; S Tomas Zenobius
myths.title: Terrestrial Globe (Gerardus Mercator, 1541)
myths.title2: Nova totius terrarum orbis iuxta neotericorum traditiones descriptio (Abraham Ortelius, 1564)
myths.description:
Gerardus Mercator writing in his 1595 atlas stated:

Only two habitations in the extreme North, namely in Greenland, are known to us, Alba (11°W, 74°45'N) and St Thomas monastery (16°W 75°12'N).

Mercator's reference to a monastery here may stem from a legendary miracle first recounted in an English translation of the 14th century travelogue of Sir John Mandeville. The story is set in Tile (Thule) - the furthest isle of the world inhabited with men.

When the Christian king of this isle fell sick and was on his deathbed, St. Thomas of Canterbury appeared to him in a vision, instructing him to build a church dedicated to him. The king followed his instructions and as soon as the first stone was laid the king's illness lifted.

The monastery was mentioned again in the narrative of a 14th-century voyage taken by the Zeno brothers, published nearly two centuries later by a descendent in 1558. While on the search for new land, Nicolo Zeno discovered a monastery of the order of Friars Preachers (Dominicans) and a church dedicated to Saint Thomas, '...hard by a hill which vomited fire like Vesuvius and Etna'. The narrative further explained how springs of hot water allowed the monks to live comfortably here in the harsh conditions of this northerly latitude.

The Thomas referenced by the later Zeno narrative implies the church was dedicated to St. Thomas Aquinas, canonized in 1323, rather than St. Thomas of Canterbury (Thomas Becket) referenced in Mandeville's Travels and who was canonized in 1173.

Some have hypothesised the monastery still stands today, not in Greenland but as Newport Tower in Rhode Island. The more widely accepted opinion is that this stone building is a 16th-century windmill.

myths.name: Alba
myths.title: Terrestrial Globe (Gerardus Mercator, 1541)
myths.title2: Americae nova Tabula (Joan Blaeu, 1665)
myths.description:
Gerardus Mercator writing in his 1595 atlas stated:

Only two habitations in the extreme North, namely in Greenland, are known to us, Alba (11°W, 74°45'N) and St Thomas monastery (16°W 75°12'N).

While legends about monks living in the far north of Greenland have been relatively well written on, little information is known about the city of Alba, supposedly 152 km away according to Mercator's coordinates.

Answers may lie in a now-lost book, Inventio Fortunata, a source Mercator had used to create his unique map of the North Pole. The book is said to be a travelogue written by a 14th-century Franciscan (Minorite) friar from Oxford who travelled the North Atlantic region in the early 1360s.

The maps Mercator created proved influential, with these High North settlements persisting on maps into the late 17th century.

myths.name: Peary Channel
myths.title: Polar regions. Baffin Bay to Lincoln Sea. From Report of R. E. Peary, C.E., U.S.N., on Work Done in the Arctic in 1898-1902 (Robert E. Peary, 1903)
myths.title2: Map Shewing Route of the North Greenland Expedition of 1891-92 (Royal Geographical Society, 1893)
myths.description:
Near the end of the 19th century little was still known about the High Arctic, including whether Greenland extended all the way to the North Pole. Such questions motivated the American, Robert E. Peary, to organise an expedition from 1891-1892 that would explore the northern reaches of Greenland.

After crossing the ice sheet, Peary reached Navy Cliff in NE Greenland. From this 1,000 m-high viewpoint Peary saw the heads of Independence Fjord (he reached it on July 4) to the east and Nordenskiöld Fjord in the west.

Peary made the assumption these fjords connected and thus confirmed the insularity of Greenland. Writing in 1898, he stated: 'It was evident that this channel marked the northern boundary of the mainland of Greenland.'

The search for this phantom channel would have disastorous consequences for the Denmark Expedition (1906-1908), whose objective was to map these last blank sections of coastline in NE Greenland. Ludvig Mylius-Erichsen and his sledge team arrived at Independence Fjord late in season in 1907. Though they found Peary's cairn at Navy Cliff they also discovered the fjord ended at Academy Glacier - conclusively determining that the Peary Channel did not exist.

Their supplies had dwindled though, and sudden mild weather had melted away their sledge route back to their ship. Forced inland, the three-man team died of exhaustion within a few months.

myths.name: Clerk Island
myths.title: British North America (Dominion Of Canada And Newfoundland) (W & A.K. Johnston, 1893)
myths.description:
This island was sighted by John Richardson on 1 August, 1826, during the Mackenzie River Expedition, and was noted only as 'a high island, lying ten or twelve miles from the shore'. It was named Sir George Clerk's Island, after the then Lord of the Admiralty. Over the years this mouthful of a name became shortened to simply Clerk Island.

People were still searching for the island during the 20th century, including Roald Amundsen in 1905, en route to become the first person to traverse the Northwest Passage.

As with many phantom islands reported in polar regions, the original sighting of land may simply have been that of a dirty iceberg. Eventually the island faded from maps, sometimes left as just a small marking near Dolphin and Union Strait.

myths.name: President Land
myths.title: The Arctic Expedition: Map of the Smith Sound route to the North Polar Sea. (E.G. Ravenstein, 1875)
myths.description:
During the doomed Polaris Expedition from 1871-73 - the first Arctic mission of its kind to be funded in its entirety by the US Government - land was sighted far north of Greenland at ~84°N. Charles Francis Hall, the leader of the expedition, would later die under suspicious circumstances after having failed to reach their target of the North Pole.

President Land subsequently appeared on a map of Greenland featured in the Illustrated London News in 1875. Not long after though, a British expedition to try and reach the North Pole led by Sir George Nares reported back the following year that President Land did not exist.

myths.name: Onaseuse
myths.title: Australia und Polynesia zur Ubersicht der Entdeckung und Colonisation (Karl von Spruner, 1855)
myths.title2: Map of American Polynesia (August Petermann, 1859)
myths.description:
In the Asiatic Journal for May 1824, there appeared an article titled 'New Island in the Southern Ocean' - a discovery of Captain Hunter of the Dona Carmelita.

The report gave a detailed account of this 'most beautiful and well cultivated' island, around 250 km northwest of Fiji (15°31'S, 176°11'E), as well as the natives they met. Notably, the island was entirely composed of lava, and in some places, almost a metal.

The Chief Officer and some of the crew went ashore to meet the King of the island, to whom they gifted a white shirt and looking glass. In return the King gifted the crew a hog, yams, bananas and cocoa-nuts.

The islanders were described as all having had their little fingers on their left hand cut off at the second joint. In addition, the women had their cheek bones perforated, 'and the blood smeared round about an inch'.

Despite the detailed information about the island it was never found again. However, rather than being a fabricated story, it appears the 'discovery' of Onaseuse is a case of mistaken positioning.

In 1869, Prof Meinicke theorised that Captain Hunter had mistakenly placed the reported longitude in the wrong hemisphere. Instead, they had come across the volcanic island of Niuafoʻou in Tonga (15°36'S, 175°38'W). This island had been visited previously in 1791 by the British Capt. Edwards, who had reported the natives calling it Onooasaw. Furthermore, the observation of removed finger parts can be related to a pre-Christian tradition in Tonga that occurred during periods of mourning.

myths.name: Brinsmade
myths.title: West-Polynesien (Adolf Stieler, 1852)
myths.description:
In 1840, Captain Wood of the ship L.C. Richmond found what he considered a new island at 15°37'S, 175°23'W, and named it Brinsmade after the then American Consul in Honolulu. He noted it was well wooded and apparently 'thickly inhabited' judging by the lights seen on shore at night.

It was in fact the Tongan island of Niuafoʻou, which had already been visited by Westerners several times and had been the subject of another map myth - Onaseuse.

Despite the coordinates given by Wood, some mapmakers ended up placing Brinsmade nearer Fiji in the Eastern Hemisphere, adding to the confusion.

myths.name: L'Enfant Perdu
myths.title: South America (Thomas Jeffreys, 1776)
myths.description:
Discovered by Louis Antoine de Bougainville on 11 May 1768 at 14°20'S, 176°40'W during his circumnavigation of the world, though it was only seen from a distance of 7 leagues (39 km).

At first it was considered to be the Horn Islands (Futuna and Alofi) first discovered by Le Maire and Schouten, though the somewhat distant position given by Bougainville suggested it could indeed have been a separate island.

myths.name: Tamana
myths.title: Western Pacific Ocean (Charles Wilkes, 1845)
myths.title2: Australien (Heinrich Kiepert, 1868)
myths.description:
The appearance of a Tamana island in the Gilbert Islands north of the equator was the result of not one, but two cartographic blunders.

The first occurred after the discovery of New Nantucket Island in 1818 by Captain Elisha Folger. Also known as Phoebe Island prior to its renaming to Baker Island, the island ended up mistakenly transposed on some maps into the Eastern Hemisphere.

The second mistake followed during the United States Exploring Expedition of 1838-42, when Lieutenant Charles Wilkes learned from natives the names of five islands in the Gilbert Group that he had not yet seen. Tamana was one of these names and his error was to assume it belonged to the earlier misplaced Phoebe Island, rather than where it is actually found south of the equator in the location of Rotcher Island.

myths.name: Sequeiras
myths.pseudonym: Ihla de Gomes de Sequeira; Martyros; Martires; Matelotas; Catritan; Catricon; Cafrifan
myths.title: The Philippin, Carolin, Moluka and Spice Islands (S. Boulton, 1755)
myths.title2: No. 6.Ostliche Halbkugel (Karl Sohr, 1888)
myths.description:
The first penetration of the Portuguese into the Pacific in 1525 resulted in a map myth that would survive for four centuries. Left stranded by a storm 200-300 leagues (1,287-1,931 km) northeast of the Molucca Passage, Diego da Rocha came across a group of inhabited islands where they recuperated for the next few months. He named the islands after his pilot: Ihla de Gomes de Sequeira.

Some contemporary accounts placed the islands at a latitude of 9 or 10 degrees north. When knowledge of the nearby Palau Group became more widespread in Europe at the start of the 18th century, it was generally assumed that it was this island nation that da Rocha had visited.

A sighting in 1802 of three islands northwest of the Palau Group revived the old myth. The Spanish captain Don Joaquín Lafita of the frigate Príncipe de Asturias reported these to be 'discoveries from ancient times' that had been noted on old Spanish charts, namely Martires (Pulap), Matalotes (Fais/Ngulu) and Cafrifan (unknown). Were these the islands da Roche had visited too?

No islands were ever found at the coordinates confidently provided by Lafita and eventually these names disappeared from maps entirely. However, the legend of the Sequeiras islands persisted on maps through the 19th century. More recently, it has been speculated that da Rocha had actually reached Ulithi atoll - the westernmost of the Caroline Islands.

myths.name: Mallon's Island
myths.title: L'Oceanie (Alexandre Emile Lapie, 1829)
myths.description: Potentially a mis-charting of nearby Johnston Atoll, or a misplaced Wake Island from the Eastern Hemisphere. Its earliest reference can be found in The New American Practical Navigator of 1826 by Nathaniel Bowditch.

myths.name: Buchile Island
myths.description:
This reported position for Buchile Island was investigated by Captain Juan E. Lopez in 1874 while commanding the Chilean corvette O' Higgins. With soundings made to depths of 465 fathoms (850 m) without obtaining bottom, the island was proven to be false.

Only one appearance of this island on a chart has been found - on Admiralty Chart No 2683 of the Pacific Ocean first published in 1859.

myths.name: beatosu and goblu
myths.title: Michigan Great Lake State (P Fletcher, 1978)
myths.title2: Toledo Blade 31 Jan 1980
myths.description:
'Paper towns' are a well-known copyright trap to catch out potential plagiarists. However, the appearance of beatosu and goblu on the 1978 Michigan state road map added a new variation to this concept.

Neither town actually exists, but for Peter Fletcher, the former chairman of the Michigan State Highway Commission and an avid University of Michigan football fan, sneaking some motivational slogans into the latest state road map seemed like the perfect tribute.

Fletcher ordered a cartographer to insert the two names - beatosu (ie. beat rivals Ohio State University) and goblu (Go blue!).

The fake towns lie outside Michigan state lines, outside the map's focus. "We have no legal liability for anything taking place in that intellectual swamp south of Monroe," Mr. Fletcher jokingly commented when asked about the prank.

The mistake did not go unnoticed by the public and a reprint of the map was soon ordered. Surviving copies that include the imaginary towns have now become collectables.

myths.name: Mount Richard
myths.title: Boulder County road map (Richard J. Ciacci, 1971)
myths.title2: Google Maps 2025
myths.description:
At least one landmark went missing from the 1976 Boulder County Road Map. Since 1971, the imaginary peak of Mt. Richard had appeared in the mountain area near the county border.

Mt. Richard's disappearance coincided with the departure of Richard J. Ciacci, a part-time draftsman who used to prepare the county road maps.

Ciacci's replacement, Carl Simmons, who left Mt. Richard off the 1976 iteration, told the Daily Camera, 'The county road map is a serious document and I wouldn't tamper with it.'

myths.name: Argleton
myths.title: Google Maps c. 2008
myths.title2: Google Maps 2025
myths.description:
Argleton was a phantom town that appeared on Google Maps and Google Earth until its removal in May 2010.

The error was first highlighted in 2008 by Mike Nolan, a local resident who brought attention of the mistake to local media.

By 2009 the story gained worldwide attention, with the town also becoming the subject of several spoof websites (now defunct). Yet visitors to its supposed location would find just empty fields.

Google did not acknowledge this was a deliberate copyright trap. Tele Atlas, the supplier of cartographic data for Google, was similarly unable to explain the anomaly in its database.

myths.name: Samak
myths.title: Plan Particulier du Golfe de Perse depuis le Caps de Rosalgatte et de Jasque, jusqu'à Bassora. (Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette, 1745)
myths.title2: A New Map of Arabia: Divided into Its Several Regions and Districts. (Jean-Baptiste Bourguignon d'Anville, 1794)
myths.description:
Parts of the Persian Gulf were still a mystery to western geographers during the 18th century, particularly along its western shore. The most egregious mistakes included the absence of the Qatar Peninsula, seemingly replaced by Samak Island.

Although the peninsula had been included on some maps from two centuries earlier, this particular error (perpetuated mostly on French maps) appears to have stemmed from an influential chart of the Persian Gulf prepared by Jean Baptiste Nicolas Denis d'Apres de Mannevillette in 1745.

During his many voyages d'Apres de Mannevillette created a number of charts for his hydrographic atlas, Le Neptune Oriental. However, the French Admiralty considered the maps to be so accurate many first edition copies were ordered to be destroyed so as to protect French interests in the Far East.

d'Apres de Mannevillette's charting mistakes along this coastline were likely due to the abundance of shallow coral reefs here preventing access to deep ocean-going vessels. The duplication of the major island of Bahrain as Samak (translated to fish) can be traced to an early alternative name that was used for this island.

myths.name: Terre de Yesso
myths.pseudonym: Iesso; Yeco; Eso; Jesso; Yedso; Yezo
myths.title: Carte des Indes et de la Chine (Guillaume de L'Isle, 1742)
myths.title2: Mare del Sud detto alurimenti Mare Pacifico (Vincenzo Coronelli, 1693)
myths.title3: A New and Correct Map of the World Laid Down According to the Newest Discoveries, and from the Most Exact Observations (Herman Moll, c.1730)
myths.description:
In 1643, the Dutchman Maarten Gerritszoon (de) Vries became one of the first Europeans to visit Hokkaido, or Ezo as these northern lands were historically referred to by the Japanese. He was on a mission searching for fabled islands of gold and silver.

Notably, it was during this voyage that de Vries also sighted two other lands that would feature heavily in the mismapping of this region over the coming decades: Compagnies Land and Staten Land.

Despite Japanese contemporary knowledge of Yesso's insularity, European cartographers would go on to depict Yesso in a range of ways, ranging from a small island, a peninsula connected to the Asian mainland, or as a near-continent sized landmass spanning the north Pacific.

The region would not be accurately charted by Europeans until around the 1780s, helped in part by the French explorer La Perouse who sailed through a strait to the north of Yesso and established its separation from the continent.
